abstract: Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education, program under the Affordable Care Act that trains doctors in underserved communities, faces uncertain future amid Congressional debate; communities nationwide, like Harlem in New York City, could soon be deprived of hundreds of primary care physicians.
headline: Amid Affordable Care Act Fight, a Health Center Program Struggles to Stay Alive
paragraph: The future is uncertain for a program that trains doctors in underserved communities as it tries to tackle a worsening shortage of primary care physicians.
text: Amid Affordable Care Act Fight, a Health Center Program Struggles to Stay Alive The future is uncertain for a program that trains doctors in underserved communities as it tries to tackle a worsening shortage of primary care physicians. Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education, program under the Affordable Care Act that trains doctors in underserved communities, faces uncertain future amid Congressional debate; communities nationwide, like Harlem in New York City, could soon be deprived of hundreds of primary care physicians.

abstract: Supporters of impending medical marijuana program in New York State worry that measure is so strict that it will prevent many deserving patients from receiving the drug; Health Dept restrictions include only 10 qualifying conditions, would prevent smoking of the drug, and would limit consumption to only 5 medical brands.
headline: New York State’s Medical Marijuana Rules Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive
paragraph: With the state close to issuing final regulations, supporters of the new program are concerned that some of its constraints will harm its effectiveness.
text: New York State’s Medical Marijuana Rules Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive With the state close to issuing final regulations, supporters of the new program are concerned that some of its constraints will harm its effectiveness. Supporters of impending medical marijuana program in New York State worry that measure is so strict that it will prevent many deserving patients from receiving the drug; Health Dept restrictions include only 10 qualifying conditions, would prevent smoking of the drug, and would limit consumption to only 5 medical brands.

headline: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea
paragraph: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year.
text: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year.

headline: Health Agency Reports Lowest Weekly Total of New Ebola Cases
paragraph: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus.
text: Health Agency Reports Lowest Weekly Total of New Ebola Cases The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus.

abstract: Gadgetwise column highlights project undertaken by photographer Vincent Laforet, in which he has taken aerial photos of cities in dark without flash, in order to illustrate stunning technological advances digital photography has made.

Gadgetwise column highlights project undertaken by photographer Vincent Laforet, in which he has taken aerial photos of cities in dark without flash, in order to illustrate stunning technological advances digital photography has made.

abstract: World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancers says glyphosate, active ingredient in Roundup herbicide, is probably carcinogenic to humans; Monsanto, which manufactures herbicide, disputes findings.

abstract: Governments and relief organizations around world take of stock of mistakes made in responding to Ebola outbreak in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea; lessons learned may help limit future epidemics.

abstract: Turkish politician Mehmet Ali Ediboglu tells British newspaper The Observer that he believes six medical students and three recent graduates, all Britons, have secretly traveled to Syria to work in region under Islamic State control.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column criticizes distortion of facts by conservatives bent on portraying Affordable Care Act as economic disaster; holds whatever one's viewpoint, law is costing taxpayers far less than expected, and has not emerged as job-killer; argues conservative campaign belies an unsettling disregard for facts in politics, and unwillingness to concede arguments in face of overwhelming evidence.

abstract: Some advanced medical centers and doctors are pushing to provide patients with better access to their records, arguing that better-informed patients are more likely to take care of themselves and detect early signs of illness; participants in OpenNotes initiative allow patients access online; doctoral student Steven Keating, who has rigorously collected his own records and who detected signs of brain tumor, is example of trend's potential.
headline: The Healing Power of Your Own Medical Records
paragraph: There is evidence that letting patients see their medical files helps them take better care of themselves, but the medical establishment still resists sharing the data.

abstract: Liberian government issues recommendation, supported by United Nations health experts, that survivors of Ebola practice safe sex until more data is available concerning how long the virus can remain viable in body fluids.

abstract: World Health Organization's declaration that glyphosate, active ingredient in Monsanto weed killer Roundup, likely causes cancer in humans shows how scientific data can be interpreted differently by different organizations; agency's research was in part based on study used by Environmental Protection Agency to reverse itself and approve use of Roundup, six years after using same study to suggest that it may cause cancer.
headline: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted
paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.
text: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer. World Health Organization's declaration that glyphosate, active ingredient in Monsanto weed killer Roundup, likely causes cancer in humans shows how scientific data can be interpreted differently by different organizations; agency's research was in part based on study used by Environmental Protection Agency to reverse itself and approve use of Roundup, six years after using same study to suggest that it may cause cancer.

abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column contrasts lives of Isabel dos Santos, daughter of Angolan Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos and one of richest women in Africa, and Delfina Fernandes, impoverished resident of village of Kibanga; notes vast gulf between their lives is in many ways due to corruption in government, as Angola has one of richest pools of natural wealth per capita, yet country does nothing for vast majority of its citizens.

headline: Greece's Tsipras Aims to Bolster Public Health Care
paragraph: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said Thursday his government will bolster public health care in Greece through the hiring of 4,500 specialized staff and the abolition of a compulsory 5-euro ($5.4) fee for treatment at public hospitals.
text: Greece's Tsipras Aims to Bolster Public Health Care Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said Thursday his government will bolster public health care in Greece through the hiring of 4,500 specialized staff and the abolition of a compulsory 5-euro ($5.4) fee for treatment at public hospitals.

headline: Audit: Maryland Misallocated $28.4M for Health Exchange
paragraph: Maryland misallocated $28.4 million in federal money for its flawed health care exchange and should pay the money back, according to a federal audit released Friday.
text: Audit: Maryland Misallocated $28.4M for Health Exchange Maryland misallocated $28.4 million in federal money for its flawed health care exchange and should pay the money back, according to a federal audit released Friday.

headline: Former Singaporean PM's health deteriorates further

headline: Singaporeans Leave Flowers, Cards as Lee's Health Worsens

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Robert M Wachter identifies some reasons why health care professionals dislike electronic medical record systems; cites inefficiency and frequent errors that result from using them; disagrees with those who propose scrapping electronic records altogether; suggests changes to way doctors organize work are in order, and calls for more collaboration between academic researchers and software developers.
headline: Why Health Care Tech Is Still So Bad
paragraph: Electronic records will transform medicine, eventually.
text: Why Health Care Tech Is Still So Bad Electronic records will transform medicine, eventually. Op-Ed article by Prof Robert M Wachter identifies some reasons why health care professionals dislike electronic medical record systems; cites inefficiency and frequent errors that result from using them; disagrees with those who propose scrapping electronic records altogether; suggests changes to way doctors organize work are in order, and calls for more collaboration between academic researchers and software developers.

abstract: Op-Ed article by obstetrician and gynecologist Claire A Putnam details the many dangers and complications that are more likely to crop up in pregnant women who are obese, both for mother's health and for the child's; underscores importance of doctors discussing with their pregnant patients the dangers of obesity.

abstract: The Upshot; research by University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute and Robert Wood Johnson Foundation finds evidence that suggests residents of communities with high income inequality are more likely to experience shorter live spans; study lends credence to theory that areas of higher income inequality will have less social cohesion and investment in education and public health.

abstract: Analysis by Kaiser Family Foundation finds that half of households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums in 2014 under Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to federal government.
headline: Many Will Need to Repay Health Subsidies
paragraph: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

abstract: Breast milk is among latest frontiers of biotechnology industry, thereby becoming an industrial commodity; researchers say they hope to synthesize and distill variety of potential therapeutics from breast milk for treatment of varied diseases; skeptics of fledgling industry have expressed concerns, particularly about how it will impact nonprofit milk banks.

headline: Nebraska Health Care Worker Being Monitored for Ebola Has Unrelated Health Issue: Hospital
paragraph: One of five people being monitored by an Omaha, Nebraska medical center after possible exposure to the Ebola virus in West Africa has been hospitalized for a health problem unrelated to Ebola, health officials said on Sunday.
text: Nebraska Health Care Worker Being Monitored for Ebola Has Unrelated Health Issue: Hospital One of five people being monitored by an Omaha, Nebraska medical center after possible exposure to the Ebola virus in West Africa has been hospitalized for a health problem unrelated to Ebola, health officials said on Sunday.

abstract: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne, pointing to rising tax receipts and falling inflation, claims that his spending cuts have given rise to economic rebound; opposition Labor Party disputes claim.
headline: George Osborne Offers Tax Breaks to British Voters in Budget Statement

abstract: Fate of bipartisan health care deal put together by Rep Nancy Pelosi and House Speaker John Boehner is uncertain, as Sen Harry Reid's objection to abortion provision may stall bill in Senate; Reid's dissent signals reversal of congressional dynamic, with Democrats waging ideological battle from disadvantaged position, tactic long used by Republicans.
headline: Bipartisan Deal on Health Care Issues Hits a Snag Among Senate Democrats
paragraph: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada and other Democrats have begun to undermine what was poised to be a sweeping bipartisan solution to several policy problems that have long vexed Congress.
text: Bipartisan Deal on Health Care Issues Hits a Snag Among Senate Democrats Senator Harry Reid of Nevada and other Democrats have begun to undermine what was poised to be a sweeping bipartisan solution to several policy problems that have long vexed Congress. Fate of bipartisan health care deal put together by Rep Nancy Pelosi and House Speaker John Boehner is uncertain, as Sen Harry Reid's objection to abortion provision may stall bill in Senate; Reid's dissent signals reversal of congressional dynamic, with Democrats waging ideological battle from disadvantaged position, tactic long used by Republicans.

headline: Nearly 11.7 Million Signed Up for Obamacare Health Insurance - HHS
paragraph: Nearly 11.7 million people have either signed up or re-enrolled for insurance coverage under the U.S. healthcare reform law, more than the 9.1 million predicted by the Obama administration,    health officials said on Tuesday.
text: Nearly 11.7 Million Signed Up for Obamacare Health Insurance - HHS Nearly 11.7 million people have either signed up or re-enrolled for insurance coverage under the U.S. healthcare reform law, more than the 9.1 million predicted by the Obama administration,    health officials said on Tuesday.

abstract: The House is set to give strong bipartisan support to a health deal negotiated between Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Nancy Pelosi.

text: Today in Politics: Health Fix Heralds Rare Moment of Congressional Compromise   The House is set to give strong bipartisan support to a health deal negotiated between Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Nancy Pelosi.

headline: Paid to Sleep: NY Cracks Down on Napping Health Workers
paragraph: By day, Tanya Lemon was a 35-year-old single mother who took care of her four children. By night, she worked 12-hour shifts as a nurse at a state group home in suburban Syracuse, paid to watch over vulnerable residents as they slept.
text: Paid to Sleep: NY Cracks Down on Napping Health Workers By day, Tanya Lemon was a 35-year-old single mother who took care of her four children. By night, she worked 12-hour shifts as a nurse at a state group home in suburban Syracuse, paid to watch over vulnerable residents as they slept.

headline: Indiana to Declare Public Health Emergency Over HIV Outbreak
paragraph: Faced with a growing HIV outbreak tied to intravenous drug use, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence said Wednesday he's considering a needle-exchange program as part of a public health emergency he's preparing to declare in a county that's at the epicenter of the cases.
text: Indiana to Declare Public Health Emergency Over HIV Outbreak Faced with a growing HIV outbreak tied to intravenous drug use, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence said Wednesday he's considering a needle-exchange program as part of a public health emergency he's preparing to declare in a county that's at the epicenter of the cases.

headline: China's Huawei Given Clean Bill of Health by UK Security Board
paragraph: China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd [HWT.UL], the telecoms equipment company whose products are now integral to various mobile and fixed-line networks, poses no threat to Britain's national security, a board established to monitor the company's operations said.
text: China's Huawei Given Clean Bill of Health by UK Security Board China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd [HWT.UL], the telecoms equipment company whose products are now integral to various mobile and fixed-line networks, poses no threat to Britain's national security, a board established to monitor the company's operations said.

headline: Exclusive: Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan
paragraph: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked for a drastic cutback of an ambitious health care plan after cost estimates came in at $18.5 billion over five years, several government sources said, delaying a promise made in his election manifesto.
text: Exclusive: Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked for a drastic cutback of an ambitious health care plan after cost estimates came in at $18.5 billion over five years, several government sources said, delaying a promise made in his election manifesto.

headline: Warriors, Hawks Prioritizing Health Over NBA's Best Record

text: Warriors, Hawks Prioritizing Health Over NBA's Best Record Barring a major turn of events, the only thing the Golden State Warriors and Atlanta Hawks have left to play for is the NBA's best record.

headline: Industry Makes $7,000 for Each Tobacco Death: Health Campaigners
paragraph: The tobacco industry makes $7,000 for each of the more than 6 million people who die each year from smoking-related illness, the health campaign group World Lung Foundation (WLF) said on Thursday.
text: Industry Makes $7,000 for Each Tobacco Death: Health Campaigners The tobacco industry makes $7,000 for each of the more than 6 million people who die each year from smoking-related illness, the health campaign group World Lung Foundation (WLF) said on Thursday.

headline: Oman Sultan Returns in 'Complete Health' After Treatment in Germany
paragraph: Oman's Sultan Qaboos returned home "in complete health" on Monday after an eight-month medical stay in Germany, state television reported, adding his treatment had been a success.
text: Oman Sultan Returns in 'Complete Health' After Treatment in Germany Oman's Sultan Qaboos returned home "in complete health" on Monday after an eight-month medical stay in Germany, state television reported, adding his treatment had been a success.

headline: Poll: Public Unaware Obama's Health Law Is Again in Jeopardy

text: Poll: Public Unaware Obama's Health Law Is Again in Jeopardy With a decision due by summer in a Supreme Court case that could unravel President Barack Obama's health care law, a new poll finds many Americans have heard nothing about the case.

headline: Five U.S. Health Workers Released After Ebola Monitoring in Nebraska
paragraph: Five U.S. healthcare workers who underwent monitoring at a Nebraska medical center after possible exposure to the Ebola virus in West Africa have completed their quarantine periods and were symptom-free, the hospital said on Tuesday.
text: Five U.S. Health Workers Released After Ebola Monitoring in Nebraska Five U.S. healthcare workers who underwent monitoring at a Nebraska medical center after possible exposure to the Ebola virus in West Africa have completed their quarantine periods and were symptom-free, the hospital said on Tuesday.

headline: Lukewarm Reception for New Sign-Up Period Under Health Law

headline: Delta Air Lines Helps Gay Employees With Health Care Taxes

text: Delta Air Lines Helps Gay Employees With Health Care Taxes Delta Air Lines became the first major carrier Thursday to make same-sex domestic partners whole for additional income taxes they owe for health care plans.

headline: Health Providers' Stand Could Invite Other Execution Methods

headline: Liberia: Families of Health Workers Killed by Ebola Get $5k
paragraph: Liberia's government has begun making payments to the families of health workers who died of Ebola in the world's worst ever outbreak, an official said Thursday.
text: Liberia: Families of Health Workers Killed by Ebola Get $5k Liberia's government has begun making payments to the families of health workers who died of Ebola in the world's worst ever outbreak, an official said Thursday.

headline: Emails: UN Health Agency Resisted Declaring Ebola Emergency
paragraph: In a delay that some say may have cost lives, the World Health Organization resisted calling the Ebola outbreak in West Africa a public health emergency until last summer, two months after staff raised the possibility and long after a senior manager called for a drastic change in strategy, The Associated Press has learned.
text: Emails: UN Health Agency Resisted Declaring Ebola Emergency In a delay that some say may have cost lives, the World Health Organization resisted calling the Ebola outbreak in West Africa a public health emergency until last summer, two months after staff raised the possibility and long after a senior manager called for a drastic change in strategy, The Associated Press has learned.

headline: Mental Health Vetting of Pilots Ineffective, US Experts Say
paragraph: There is little effective, real-world screening of airline pilots for mental problems despite regulations in the U.S., Europe and elsewhere that say mental health should be part of their regular medical exams, pilots and safety experts said.
text: Mental Health Vetting of Pilots Ineffective, US Experts Say There is little effective, real-world screening of airline pilots for mental problems despite regulations in the U.S., Europe and elsewhere that say mental health should be part of their regular medical exams, pilots and safety experts said.

headline: Exclusive-Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan
paragraph: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked for a drastic cutback of an ambitious health care plan after cost estimates came in at $18.5 billion over five years, several government sources said, delaying a promise made in his election manifesto.
text: Exclusive-Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked for a drastic cutback of an ambitious health care plan after cost estimates came in at $18.5 billion over five years, several government sources said, delaying a promise made in his election manifesto.

abstract: Senator Ted Cruz helped lead an effort to shut down the government in 2013 in an attempt to defund President Obama’s health care law. Now, he is signing up for coverage under it.
headline: Cruz, Critic of Health Care Law, Now Seeks to Sign Up
text: Cruz, Critic of Health Care Law, Now Seeks to Sign Up   Senator Ted Cruz helped lead an effort to shut down the government in 2013 in an attempt to defund President Obama’s health care law. Now, he is signing up for coverage under it.

abstract: Kaiser Health Tracking Poll finds 43 percent of respondents have unfavorable view of Affordable Care Act while 41 percent view it favorably, smallest gap between two sides since fall of 2012; also finds majority of respondents worry about Supreme Court case that could limit health insurance subsidies.
headline: Poll on Health Care Law Shows Increased Support
paragraph: The gap between Americans who view the Affordable Care Act favorably and those who do not is smaller than at any time since 2012, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation poll.
text: Poll on Health Care Law Shows Increased Support The gap between Americans who view the Affordable Care Act favorably and those who do not is smaller than at any time since 2012, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation poll. Kaiser Health Tracking Poll finds 43 percent of respondents have unfavorable view of Affordable Care Act while 41 percent view it favorably, smallest gap between two sides since fall of 2012; also finds majority of respondents worry about Supreme Court case that could limit health insurance subsidies.

abstract: New York State prepares to initiate experimental Medicaid program that will eventually reward health care providers who improve conditions of their patients; state-federal partnership will include 25 high-volume practices that serve disadvantaged communities; will seek to incentivize closer monitoring and preventative care in order to reduce enormous public cost of hospital and emergency visits.
headline: Pay for Performance Extends to Health Care in New York State Experiment
paragraph: In a state-federal partnership, 25 groups are part of a trial that would eventually reward health care providers if the conditions of their Medicaid patients improve.

abstract: Many Americans filing 2014 taxes are for first time grappling with effects of gaining insurance under Affordable Care Act, including confusing new tax forms and unexpected fees.
headline: Under Health Care Act, Many Tax Filers Are Discovering Costly Complications
paragraph: Under the Affordable Care Act, people who remained uninsured last year must either pay a penalty with their taxes or claim an exemption.
text: Under Health Care Act, Many Tax Filers Are Discovering Costly Complications Under the Affordable Care Act, people who remained uninsured last year must either pay a penalty with their taxes or claim an exemption. Many Americans filing 2014 taxes are for first time grappling with effects of gaining insurance under Affordable Care Act, including confusing new tax forms and unexpected fees.

abstract: Pilot program in Hennepin County, Minn, which encompasses Minneapolis, is one of many in country that seeks to better manage cases of so-called super utilizers of hospital care, who are often poor, homeless, or suffer from mental illness or addiction; Hennepin program focuses on 10,000 people and tries to fix their problems before they evolve into serious medical issues; such programs have raised questions of degree to which health system has role in tackling issues like poverty.
headline: Health Care Systems Try to Cut Costs by Aiding the Poor and Troubled
paragraph: Some of the most expensive patients — so-called super utilizers of hospital care — rack up costs for avoidable reasons. Experiments across the country are trying to better manage these cases.
text: Health Care Systems Try to Cut Costs by Aiding the Poor and Troubled Some of the most expensive patients — so-called super utilizers of hospital care — rack up costs for avoidable reasons. Experiments across the country are trying to better manage these cases. Pilot program in Hennepin County, Minn, which encompasses Minneapolis, is one of many in country that seeks to better manage cases of so-called super utilizers of hospital care, who are often poor, homeless, or suffer from mental illness or addiction; Hennepin program focuses on 10,000 people and tries to fix their problems before they evolve into serious medical issues; such programs have raised questions of degree to which health system has role in tackling issues like poverty.

abstract: Federal Judge Frederic Block rules that Brooklyn man Damion Hardy is competent to stand trial, ending eight years of wrangling over his mental state following 2004 arrest on charges that he led drug crew and ordered six murders; defense lawyers had long argued that Hardy, who remains on antipsychotic medication, suffered from debilitating schizophrenia.
headline: Damion Hardy’s Murder Trial Begins, After 10 Years of Sanity Arguments
paragraph: Mr. Hardy’s lawyers had argued that their client, a Brooklyn man who has schizophrenia, was not mentally competent to stand trial.
text: Damion Hardy’s Murder Trial Begins, After 10 Years of Sanity Arguments Mr. Hardy’s lawyers had argued that their client, a Brooklyn man who has schizophrenia, was not mentally competent to stand trial. Federal Judge Frederic Block rules that Brooklyn man Damion Hardy is competent to stand trial, ending eight years of wrangling over his mental state following 2004 arrest on charges that he led drug crew and ordered six murders; defense lawyers had long argued that Hardy, who remains on antipsychotic medication, suffered from debilitating schizophrenia.

abstract: German airline Lufthansa faces mounting scrutiny over crash of one of its Germanwings planes in French alps, particularly in regard to airline's admission that it was aware co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had undergone period of severe depression.
headline: Lufthansa Faces Mounting Challenges as More Details of Germanwings Crash Emerge
paragraph: The airline instead faced perhaps the worst crisis in its history, as anger in Germany was increasingly directed toward the company and its chief executive.

German airline Lufthansa faces mounting scrutiny over crash of one of its Germanwings planes in French alps, particularly in regard to airline's admission that it was aware co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had undergone period of severe depression.

abstract: News Analysis; role that Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's mental illness may have played in jetliner crash raises concern that those with mental disorders will be stigmatized, making it less likely they will seek treatment; mental health experts caution that tendency to link mass violence with mental illness has negative effect, and laws surrounding disclosure must carefully balance public safety with privacy.
headline: Role of Illness in Germanwings Crash Raises Worry About Stigma

abstract: Study by genetics firm Decode published in journal Nature Genetics reveals in-depth picture of Icelandic population's genetic makeup, including number of previously unknown gene mutations that may play role in diseases such as Alzheimer's.
headline: In Iceland’s DNA, New Clues to Disease-Causing Genes
paragraph: The results uncovered a host of previously unknown gene mutations that may play roles in ailments as diverse as Alzheimer’s disease, heart disease and gallstones.

abstract: German authorities say Germanwings pilot Andreas Lubitz had mental illness but kept diagnosis hidden from his employer; documents found in Lubitz's home support this assertion, but there are still uncertainties regarding nature and severity of his psychiatric condition.
headline: Co-Pilot in Germanwings Crash Hid Mental Illness From Employer, Authorities Say
paragraph: Among the items found at Andreas Lubitz’s home was one doctor’s note excusing him from work the day of the crash and another that had been torn up.
text: Co-Pilot in Germanwings Crash Hid Mental Illness From Employer, Authorities Say Among the items found at Andreas Lubitz’s home was one doctor’s note excusing him from work the day of the crash and another that had been torn up. German authorities say Germanwings pilot Andreas Lubitz had mental illness but kept diagnosis hidden from his employer; documents found in Lubitz's home support this assertion, but there are still uncertainties regarding nature and severity of his psychiatric condition.

abstract: Lufthansa says Andreas Lubitz, co-pilot who crashed Germanwings jetliner in French Alps, told company in 2009 that he had suffered from severe depression; says he sent email informing airline of his condition as he was trying to rejoin its training program after absence of several months.
headline: Lufthansa Says Germanwings Pilot Reported Deep Depression
paragraph: The company said Andreas Lubitz, thought to have intentionally crashed a Germanwings flight, had informed it of his depressive episodes in 2009 after a break in training.
text: Lufthansa Says Germanwings Pilot Reported Deep Depression The company said Andreas Lubitz, thought to have intentionally crashed a Germanwings flight, had informed it of his depressive episodes in 2009 after a break in training. Lufthansa says Andreas Lubitz, co-pilot who crashed Germanwings jetliner in French Alps, told company in 2009 that he had suffered from severe depression; says he sent email informing airline of his condition as he was trying to rejoin its training program after absence of several months.

abstract: Letter from Chirlane McCray, New York City's first lady, comments on March 29 article about regulators loosening restrictions on allowing those with some forms of mental illness to pilot planes.
headline: Chirlane McCray, on the Germanwings Co-Pilot’s Mental Health
paragraph: Chirlane McCray, New York’s first lady, writes that “it’s time to recognize the stress and responsibility that pilots face and change our regulations and policies to ensure their mental health.”

abstract: Case in which Santa Fe, NM, man Arthur Firstenberg sued neighbor, alleging that electromagnetic radiation from her use of cellphones and Wi-Fi connection damaged his health, illustrates sometimes fraught relationship between legal system and sound science; Firstenberg's allegations are not backed up by science but lawsuit has resulted in hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees.
headline: When Science Is Lost in a Legal Maze
paragraph: A New Mexico case highlighted how unsubstantiated notions like the health dangers of electromagnetic signals can continue to get a serious hearing.
text: When Science Is Lost in a Legal Maze A New Mexico case highlighted how unsubstantiated notions like the health dangers of electromagnetic signals can continue to get a serious hearing. text: Ebola Vaccines Pass Initial Safety Tests Two experimental Ebola vaccines “appear to be safe” partway through a clinical trial being conducted in Liberia, the National Institutes of Health said Thursday. Two Ebola vaccines being tested on more than 600 volunteers in Liberia pass initial safety tests.

abstract: National Snow and Ice Data Center, reporting on Arctic sea ice conditions, find less ice in winter of 2014-2015 than during any winter in past four decades.
headline: Coverage of Arctic Sea Ice Shrinks to a Winter Low
paragraph: There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday.
text: Coverage of Arctic Sea Ice Shrinks to a Winter Low There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday. abstract: Chiara de Blasio, daughter of Mayor Bill de Blasio, is spokeswoman for pilot New York City program allowing teenagers to seek professional guidance and advice via text message; hopes that her personal experience with depression and drug and alcohol abuse will help remove stigma of seeking help.

abstract: Op-Ed article by former commercial pilot Andrew B McGee describes his experiences of how various pilots conducted themselves in cockpit, in light of crash of Germanwings flight that seems to have been intentionally caused by pilot; notes that he was never required to meet with psychologist.

abstract: House votes 392 to 37 to approve sweeping changes to Medicare that would establish new formula for paying doctors, increase some premiums, and extend popular children's health insurance program; vote represents most significant bipartisan policy legislation in House since Republicans regained majority in 2011.
headline: House Approves Bill on Changes to Medicare
paragraph: In a significant bipartisan move backed by President Obama, the House agreed on changing the formula for doctors’ fees and extending the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

abstract: Mentally ill Afghan woman is beaten to death and her body burned by angry mob at shrine in Kabul after being accused of burning pages from Quran; many city residents are horrified at mob's justification of the killing as a commitment to Islam, but some say act was justified if she had indeed burned pages of the Quran.
headline: A Day After a Killing, Afghans React in Horror, but Some Show Approval
paragraph: Differing responses to the mob killing in Kabul of a mentally troubled woman accused of burning the Quran show how Afghans’ commitment to Islam can clash with Western values of individual rights.
text: A Day After a Killing, Afghans React in Horror, but Some Show Approval Differing responses to the mob killing in Kabul of a mentally troubled woman accused of burning the Quran show how Afghans’ commitment to Islam can clash with Western values of individual rights. abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column argues members of Republican party, as exemplified by House Speaker John Boehner, Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker and Sen Joni Ernst, are betraying their own professed humble roots and modest class origins by working to keep struggling workers down; holds raising minimum wage and maintaining health care subsidies will strengthen economy, not weaken it as Republicans contend.
headline: Traitors to Their Class
paragraph: These Horatio Algerians for the new Gilded Age are virtuous because they made it, or vice versa. And those who haven’t managed a similar leap are just weaklings.
text: Traitors to Their Class These Horatio Algerians for the new Gilded Age are virtuous because they made it, or vice versa. And those who haven’t managed a similar leap are just weaklings. Timothy Egan Op-Ed column argues members of Republican party, as exemplified by House Speaker John Boehner, Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker and Sen Joni Ernst, are betraying their own professed humble roots and modest class origins by working to keep struggling workers down; holds raising minimum wage and maintaining health care subsidies will strengthen economy, not weaken it as Republicans contend.

abstract: Panel of police commissioners rule that Milwaukee Police Chief Ed Flynn was justified in firing Officer Christopher Manney after he fatally shot unarmed black man Dontre Hamilton.
headline: Wisconsin: Panel Upholds Firing of Officer Who Killed Homeless Man
paragraph: Milwaukee’s police chief was justified in firing a white officer who shot and killed a black man during a scuffle last April, police commissioners ruled Monday night.
text: Wisconsin: Panel Upholds Firing of Officer Who Killed Homeless Man  Milwaukee’s police chief was justified in firing a white officer who shot and killed a black man during a scuffle last April, police commissioners ruled Monday night. Panel of police commissioners rule that Milwaukee Police Chief Ed Flynn was justified in firing Officer Christopher Manney after he fatally shot unarmed black man Dontre Hamilton.

abstract: Dusseldorf, Germany, prosecutors say Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had undergone treatment for suicidal tendencies prior to receiving his pilot's license; German law leaves it up to pilots to disclose their past mental health treatment to doctors who examine them to determine whether they are fit to fly; revelation has raised questions about whether doctors should be compelled to break confidentiality if patients display suicidal tendencies.
headline: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
paragraph: The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday.
text: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say The co-pilot of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps had been treated before receiving his pilot’s license, officials said Monday. Dusseldorf, Germany, prosecutors say Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had undergone treatment for suicidal tendencies prior to receiving his pilot's license; German law leaves it up to pilots to disclose their past mental health treatment to doctors who examine them to determine whether they are fit to fly; revelation has raised questions about whether doctors should be compelled to break confidentiality if patients display suicidal tendencies.

abstract: Housing program supporting mentally ill homeless people in both New York City and New York State will expire in 2016 unless agreement is reached between Gov Andrew M Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio; coalition of advocacy groups, social service organizations and religious leaders calls for expansion of program and 30,000 new units to be created in city, but Cuomo and deBlasio have each proposed more modest plans.
headline: Uncertain Future for New York Housing Program That Helps Mentally Ill Homeless People

abstract: Crash of Germanwings Flight 9525 and revelation that co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had mental illness that he kept hidden from his employer raises questions about whether policies governing pilots with mental health issues are effective; experts say authorities should focus on improving hiring and screening process of pilots.
headline: Germanwings Crash Raises Questions About Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness

abstract: Bipartisan bill that recently cleared House of Representatives contains provision giving doctors new protections against medical malpractice suits; bill states that quality-of-care standards and guidelines used by Medicare, Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act cannot be used to show negligence by a doctor or hospital; consumer advocates have expressed concerns over provision.
headline: House Provision Offers Doctors More Protection Against Malpractice Suits
paragraph: The bill stipulates that quality standards used by Medicare, Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act should not be used to show negligence by a doctor or a hospital.
text: House Provision Offers Doctors More Protection Against Malpractice Suits The bill stipulates that quality standards used by Medicare, Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act should not be used to show negligence by a doctor or a hospital. Bipartisan bill that recently cleared House of Representatives contains provision giving doctors new protections against medical malpractice suits; bill states that quality-of-care standards and guidelines used by Medicare, Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act cannot be used to show negligence by a doctor or hospital; consumer advocates have expressed concerns over provision.

abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column examines decades-old system of tax breaks, including those for employer-provided insurance, mortgages and charity, arguing it hides function of government and shields it from public debate; observes credits are justified as alternatives to expansion of government but argues instead that system amounts to Rube Goldberg contraption excluding many in middle and working classes, with little valid claim to social purpose.
headline: The False Hope of a Limited Government, Built on Tax Breaks
paragraph: Protected from democratic accountability, the government developed into a Rube Goldberg contraption that has a weak claim to a defensible social purpose.
text: The False Hope of a Limited Government, Built on Tax Breaks Protected from democratic accountability, the government developed into a Rube Goldberg contraption that has a weak claim to a defensible social purpose. Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column examines decades-old system of tax breaks, including those for employer-provided insurance, mortgages and charity, arguing it hides function of government and shields it from public debate; observes credits are justified as alternatives to expansion of government but argues instead that system amounts to Rube Goldberg contraption excluding many in middle and working classes, with little valid claim to social purpose.

headline: Lee Kuan Yew's condition worsens- Singapore government statement
paragraph: The Singapore government says the health condition of the country's first prime minister has worsened. Julie Noce reports.
text: Lee Kuan Yew's condition worsens- Singapore government statement The Singapore government says the health condition of the country's first prime minister has worsened. Julie Noce reports.

headline: Healthways Decides Against Selling Company After Review
paragraph: Healthways' board has decided against selling the company after reviewing its strategic options to boost shareholder value.
text: Healthways Decides Against Selling Company After Review Healthways' board has decided against selling the company after reviewing its strategic options to boost shareholder value.

headline: American Who Caught Ebola Improves to Fair Condition
paragraph: Officials say an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Sierra Leone has improved to fair condition at a federal hospital.
text: American Who Caught Ebola Improves to Fair Condition Officials say an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Sierra Leone has improved to fair condition at a federal hospital.

headline: U.S. Ebola Patient's Condition Improved to Serious: NIH
paragraph: A U.S. patient being treated for the Ebola virus at a National Institutes of Health facility in Maryland has improved to serious condition from critical, the NIH said on Thursday.
text: U.S. Ebola Patient's Condition Improved to Serious: NIH A U.S. patient being treated for the Ebola virus at a National Institutes of Health facility in Maryland has improved to serious condition from critical, the NIH said on Thursday.

headline: American Who Contracted Ebola Improves, in Serious Condition
paragraph: Doctors say an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in a Sierra Leone treatment unit has improved to serious condition at the National Institutes of Health.
text: American Who Contracted Ebola Improves, in Serious Condition Doctors say an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in a Sierra Leone treatment unit has improved to serious condition at the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Texas Hospital TB Probe Ends With No Active Cases Seen
paragraph: Health officials say they found no active tuberculosis cases among infants possibly exposed to a TB-infected El Paso hospital worker.
text: Texas Hospital TB Probe Ends With No Active Cases Seen Health officials say they found no active tuberculosis cases among infants possibly exposed to a TB-infected El Paso hospital worker.

headline: Medical Expenses: Finding Your Way With a Patient Navigator
paragraph: A medical emergency leaves you with tens of thousands of dollars in unpaid hospital bills. Your health insurance company rejects coverage for an important medical test. An unexpected diagnosis requires you to find three new medical specialists.
text: Medical Expenses: Finding Your Way With a Patient Navigator A medical emergency leaves you with tens of thousands of dollars in unpaid hospital bills. Your health insurance company rejects coverage for an important medical test. An unexpected diagnosis requires you to find three new medical specialists.

headline: Guinea Trial Begins for Suspected Killers of Ebola Workers
paragraph: The trial of people accused of killing eight Ebola health workers and journalists opened Monday in a remote region of Guinea.
text: Guinea Trial Begins for Suspected Killers of Ebola Workers The trial of people accused of killing eight Ebola health workers and journalists opened Monday in a remote region of Guinea.

abstract: Ed Miliband, leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party, begins campaigning for prime minister in tightly contested election that could have wide ranging effects on country.
headline: Britain: Labour Leader Starts Bid for Prime Minister
paragraph: Ed Miliband, leader of the opposition Labour Party, began his campaign on Friday to become Britain’s next prime minister.
text: Britain: Labour Leader Starts Bid for Prime Minister Ed Miliband, leader of the opposition Labour Party, began his campaign on Friday to become Britain’s next prime minister. Ed Miliband, leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party, begins campaigning for prime minister in tightly contested election that could have wide ranging effects on country.

headline: House Medicare Deal Hits Senate Turbulence Over Abortion
paragraph: An emerging bipartisan House deal changing how Medicare reimburses doctors ran into turbulence in the Senate Thursday over abortion, spotlighting a rare public disagreement between Congress' two top Democrats.
text: House Medicare Deal Hits Senate Turbulence Over Abortion An emerging bipartisan House deal changing how Medicare reimburses doctors ran into turbulence in the Senate Thursday over abortion, spotlighting a rare public disagreement between Congress' two top Democrats.

headline: Cruz Eyes Insurance via Obamacare, a Law He Vows to Scrap
paragraph: GOP presidential candidate Ted Cruz could soon be buying his family's health care coverage through the Affordable Care Act he has vowed to dismantle.
text: Cruz Eyes Insurance via Obamacare, a Law He Vows to Scrap GOP presidential candidate Ted Cruz could soon be buying his family's health care coverage through the Affordable Care Act he has vowed to dismantle.

headline: CDC: Uninsured Drop by 11M Since Passage of Obama's Law
paragraph: The number of uninsured U.S. residents fell by more than 11 million since President Barack Obama signed the health care overhaul five years ago, according to a pair of reports Tuesday from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
text: CDC: Uninsured Drop by 11M Since Passage of Obama's Law The number of uninsured U.S. residents fell by more than 11 million since President Barack Obama signed the health care overhaul five years ago, according to a pair of reports Tuesday from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: NYC Introduces New Rules for Licensed Day Cares
paragraph: Children under 2 will not be allowed juice at New York City-licensed day cares and all other children will be limited to 4 ounces of juice a day, under new rules adopted by the city's Board of Health.
text: NYC Introduces New Rules for Licensed Day Cares Children under 2 will not be allowed juice at New York City-licensed day cares and all other children will be limited to 4 ounces of juice a day, under new rules adopted by the city's Board of Health.

headline: 5 Key Findings From AP's Story on WHO and the Ebola Outbreak
paragraph: In the aftermath of the world's biggest outbreak of Ebola, the World Health Organization acknowledged it was too slow to act, blaming factors including a lack of real-time information and the unprecedented nature of the epidemic.
text: 5 Key Findings From AP's Story on WHO and the Ebola Outbreak In the aftermath of the world's biggest outbreak of Ebola, the World Health Organization acknowledged it was too slow to act, blaming factors including a lack of real-time information and the unprecedented nature of the epidemic.

headline: Ugandan Official: Typhoid Sickens Hundreds in Capital
paragraph: An outbreak of typhoid fever has infected hundreds of people in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, and looks likely to spread as the rainy season gets under way, a senior health official said on Wednesday.
text: Ugandan Official: Typhoid Sickens Hundreds in Capital An outbreak of typhoid fever has infected hundreds of people in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, and looks likely to spread as the rainy season gets under way, a senior health official said on Wednesday.

headline: Nearly 100 Get Food Poisoning; Officials Won't Say From What
paragraph: A "food source" sickened nearly 100 restaurant patrons in Philadelphia last month, but city and state health officials say Pennsylvania law bars them from disclosing what the food was or how it was contaminated.
text: Nearly 100 Get Food Poisoning; Officials Won't Say From What A "food source" sickened nearly 100 restaurant patrons in Philadelphia last month, but city and state health officials say Pennsylvania law bars them from disclosing what the food was or how it was contaminated.

headline: Humana to Narrow Focus Outside Insurance With Concentra Sale
paragraph: Humana plans to sell occupational health care provider Concentra for about $1.06 billion, as the health insurer refines its focus on providing patient care.
text: Humana to Narrow Focus Outside Insurance With Concentra Sale Humana plans to sell occupational health care provider Concentra for about $1.06 billion, as the health insurer refines its focus on providing patient care.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JACK R
paragraph: ANDERSON--Jack R. A leader in the hospital management and HMO industries, died on March 28, 2015 at his home in Vero Beach, FL. He was 90. He was President of the start-up hospital management company, Hospital Affiliates, Inc. from 1970 until its acquisition by INA Corporation in 1981, after which he led several public health care companies. He was Chairman of Horizon Health Corporation, Republic Health Corporation, United Dental Care, Inc., TakeCare, Inc. and FHP International Corporation. He was also a director of several other companies including Quality Inns, Inc., Navistar International Corporation, and Medical Care International, Inc., He was a member of the Board of Overseers of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and a member of the Presidents' Circle for the National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering and the Institute of Medicine, Washington, DC. He authored "The Road to Recovery in 1976, a book outlining how to restore financial stability to unprofitable hospitals. Mr. Anderson was born February 14, 1925 in Mansfield, OH, where he was the youngest Eagle Scout at the time in Ohio in the Boy Scouts of America. He graduated Miami of Ohio University in 1947 and received his Masters from Columbia Business School in 1949. He served as an officer in the United States Navy during World War II, where he was assigned to a mine sweeper ship in the Pacific fleet. After returning from the War, while at Columbia, he married the love of his life, Rose-Marie Garcia Anderson, who survives him. She is a graduate of Hunter College and from Astoria, NY. He was employed at accounting and financial positions at Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner and Smith, Inc.; American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Inc.; Time Inc.; W.R. Grace & Company, Inc.; McCall Corporation and Reliance Group, Inc. In 1970 he became president and then chairman of Hospital Affiliates International, Inc. When that company was acquired by INA Corporation, he became chairman of The INA Health Care Group, Inc. which owned and managed hospitals on five continents, as well as health maintenance organizations and nursing homes in the United States. The CIGNA health plan resulted from the 1982 combination of the INA Corporation and Connecticut General Life Insurance Company. In addition to his wife, Rose-Marie, Mr. Anderson's survivors include three children, Gail Canizares, Neil Anderson, and Barbara McDonald, 11 grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Mr. Anderson travelled and read broadly, which furthered his interest in education. In 1994 he and his wife established the Anderson Foundation primarily to support efforts to improve K-12 education in America. Since that time they devoted considerable time and effort in pursuing that goal. 1/3

headline: Indiana Lawmakers to Revisit 'Baby Boxes' Bill in 2016
paragraph: Indiana lawmakers said Wednesday they will revisit a proposal next year to establish "baby boxes" for women to anonymously surrender their newborns. But first, they want the state health department to recommend protocols and a commission focused on improving children's lives to examine the plan and suggest other ways to decrease child abandonment.
text: Indiana Lawmakers to Revisit 'Baby Boxes' Bill in 2016 Indiana lawmakers said Wednesday they will revisit a proposal next year to establish "baby boxes" for women to anonymously surrender their newborns. But first, they want the state health department to recommend protocols and a commission focused on improving children's lives to examine the plan and suggest other ways to decrease child abandonment.

headline: Nurse Imprisoned in Ohio Malnutrition Death Has New Charges
paragraph: A nurse serving a 10-year prison sentence in the malnutrition death of an Ohio teenager with cerebral palsy has been charged with health care fraud.
text: Nurse Imprisoned in Ohio Malnutrition Death Has New Charges A nurse serving a 10-year prison sentence in the malnutrition death of an Ohio teenager with cerebral palsy has been charged with health care fraud.

abstract: Editorial examines Supreme Court case in which coal industry is challenging the Environmental Protection Agency's standing to regulate mercury emissions under the Clean Air Act; dismisses industry's assertion that EPA must defer to business cost of regulations; argues costs are balanced by economic benefits, including medical costs, to say nothing of human toll should they be scaled back.
headline: Clean Air Act and Dirty Coal at the Supreme Court
paragraph: The name of the law is not the Coal Industry Protection Act, despite what that industry’s advocates seem to want.
text: Clean Air Act and Dirty Coal at the Supreme Court The name of the law is not the Coal Industry Protection Act, despite what that industry’s advocates seem to want. Editorial examines Supreme Court case in which coal industry is challenging the Environmental Protection Agency's standing to regulate mercury emissions under the Clean Air Act; dismisses industry's assertion that EPA must defer to business cost of regulations; argues costs are balanced by economic benefits, including medical costs, to say nothing of human toll should they be scaled back.

headline: Britain to Offer All Infants Meningitis B Vaccine
paragraph: Britain says it will become the first country to offer all babies a vaccine for potentially fatal meningitis B after it reached a price deal with GlaxoSmithKline PLC.
text: Britain to Offer All Infants Meningitis B Vaccine Britain says it will become the first country to offer all babies a vaccine for potentially fatal meningitis B after it reached a price deal with GlaxoSmithKline PLC.

headline: Cruz Eyes Insurance via Obamacare, a Law He Vows to Scrap
paragraph: Sen. Ted Cruz could soon be buying his family's health care coverage through the Affordable Care Act, a law the Republican presidential candidate has vowed to repeal should he win the White House.
text: Cruz Eyes Insurance via Obamacare, a Law He Vows to Scrap Sen. Ted Cruz could soon be buying his family's health care coverage through the Affordable Care Act, a law the Republican presidential candidate has vowed to repeal should he win the White House.

headline: GOP-Controlled Senate Ok's Budget Plan
paragraph: The Republican-controlled Senate has approved a balanced-budget plan that calls for trillions in spending cuts and repeal of the controversial health care law to erase red ink by the end of the coming decade.
text: GOP-Controlled Senate Ok's Budget Plan The Republican-controlled Senate has approved a balanced-budget plan that calls for trillions in spending cuts and repeal of the controversial health care law to erase red ink by the end of the coming decade.

headline: Obama Says He's Ready to Sign Medicare Doctor Payment Fix
paragraph: President Barack Obama said Wednesday that he's ready to sign good bipartisan legislation to fix Medicare's doctor payment problem, without endorsing any specific legislation.
text: Obama Says He's Ready to Sign Medicare Doctor Payment Fix President Barack Obama said Wednesday that he's ready to sign good bipartisan legislation to fix Medicare's doctor payment problem, without endorsing any specific legislation.

headline: FDA Approves New Drug for Anthrax Poisoning
paragraph: Federal health officials say they have approved an infusible drug to treat patients who have been exposed to anthrax.
text: FDA Approves New Drug for Anthrax Poisoning Federal health officials say they have approved an infusible drug to treat patients who have been exposed to anthrax.

headline: New Pox Discovered in Eastern Europe, but Not Deadly
paragraph: Health officials have discovered a new germ in Eastern Europe that is related to the dreaded smallpox and monkeypox viruses but so far seems far less threatening.
text: New Pox Discovered in Eastern Europe, but Not Deadly Health officials have discovered a new germ in Eastern Europe that is related to the dreaded smallpox and monkeypox viruses but so far seems far less threatening.

headline: BOJ's Kuroda Says JGB Buying Aimed at Achieving Price Goal
paragraph: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Wednesday that the bank is buying government debt as a necessary step to achieve its 2 percent inflation target.
text: BOJ's Kuroda Says JGB Buying Aimed at Achieving Price Goal Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Wednesday that the bank is buying government debt as a necessary step to achieve its 2 percent inflation target.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVNER, YEHUDA
paragraph: AVNER--Yehuda. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the loss of Yehuda Avner. Yehuda was a passionate voice for Israel and the Jewish people, admired and respected by all. A gifted storyteller, Yehuda witnessed Israeli history, and he helped shape it. We extend our deepest condolences to the Avner and Sable families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold President and CEO David V. Pomeranz Chief Operating Officer Hebrew Home at Riverdale by RiverSpring Health 1/3

abstract: French lawmakers reject two provisions of anorexia prevention measure meant to protect professional fashion models, but leave open possibility of amended version.
headline: French Proposal on Models’ Weights Clashes With Labor Laws, Opponents Say
paragraph: A parliamentary committee rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could be approved later.
text: French Proposal on Models’ Weights Clashes With Labor Laws, Opponents Say A parliamentary committee rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could be approved later. French lawmakers reject two provisions of anorexia prevention measure meant to protect professional fashion models, but leave open possibility of amended version.

headline: Study: Fast-Food Limits Didn't Cut Obesity Rate in South LA
paragraph: A much-hailed law that restricted the opening of new stand-alone fast-food restaurants in one of the poorest sections of Los Angeles did not curb obesity or improve diets, a new study found.
text: Study: Fast-Food Limits Didn't Cut Obesity Rate in South LA A much-hailed law that restricted the opening of new stand-alone fast-food restaurants in one of the poorest sections of Los Angeles did not curb obesity or improve diets, a new study found.

headline: Texas Bill Would Bar Gun Ownership Status in Medical Record
paragraph: Texas lawmakers are considering a bill that would keep a person's gun ownership status from being listed in their medical records, a move health providers worry would be an unnecessary government intrusion that harms their consultations with patients.
text: Texas Bill Would Bar Gun Ownership Status in Medical Record Texas lawmakers are considering a bill that would keep a person's gun ownership status from being listed in their medical records, a move health providers worry would be an unnecessary government intrusion that harms their consultations with patients.

headline: UnitedHealth to Buy Pharmacy Benefit Firm Catamaran for $12.8 Billion
paragraph: Health insurer UnitedHealth Group Inc agreed to buy Catamaran Corp in a deal worth about $12.8 billion to boost its pharmacy benefit business as it competes with bigger rivals such as Express Scripts Holdings Co.
text: UnitedHealth to Buy Pharmacy Benefit Firm Catamaran for $12.8 Billion Health insurer UnitedHealth Group Inc agreed to buy Catamaran Corp in a deal worth about $12.8 billion to boost its pharmacy benefit business as it competes with bigger rivals such as Express Scripts Holdings Co.

headline: Employer Incentives for U.S. Worker Wellness Programs Set Record
paragraph: Employers have ratcheted up the financial incentives they offer workers to participate in wellness programs to a record $693 per employee, on average, this year from $594 in 2014 and $430 five years ago, found a report released on Thursday.
text: Employer Incentives for U.S. Worker Wellness Programs Set Record Employers have ratcheted up the financial incentives they offer workers to participate in wellness programs to a record $693 per employee, on average, this year from $594 in 2014 and $430 five years ago, found a report released on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Hospitals' Uncompensated Care Fell by $7.4 Billion in 2014: Government
paragraph: The costs of caring for the uninsured at U.S. hospitals fell by an estimated $7.4 billion in 2014 due to the expansion of healthcare to millions of people under Obamacare, according to a government report released on Monday.
text: U.S. Hospitals' Uncompensated Care Fell by $7.4 Billion in 2014: Government The costs of caring for the uninsured at U.S. hospitals fell by an estimated $7.4 billion in 2014 due to the expansion of healthcare to millions of people under Obamacare, according to a government report released on Monday.

headline: Monsanto Fined for Not Reporting Idaho Chemical Releases
paragraph: Monsanto Co. has agreed to pay $600,000 in fines for not reporting hundreds of uncontrolled releases of toxic chemicals at its eastern Idaho phosphate plant.
text: Monsanto Fined for Not Reporting Idaho Chemical Releases Monsanto Co. has agreed to pay $600,000 in fines for not reporting hundreds of uncontrolled releases of toxic chemicals at its eastern Idaho phosphate plant.

headline: Indian Doctors Find Success in Tackling the 'Invisible Burden' of Tuberculosis
paragraph: When Indian street-food seller Kumar Pal first began treatment for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis two years ago, he quickly spiralled into depression and gave up hope of living.
text: Indian Doctors Find Success in Tackling the 'Invisible Burden' of Tuberculosis When Indian street-food seller Kumar Pal first began treatment for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis two years ago, he quickly spiralled into depression and gave up hope of living.

headline: House Dems Say New Abortion Language Helps Medicare Doc Deal
paragraph: Language has been added to an emerging bipartisan deal on Medicare clarifying that the agreement's abortion restrictions on community health centers are temporary and won't be inscribed into permanent law, House Democrats said Monday.
text: House Dems Say New Abortion Language Helps Medicare Doc Deal Language has been added to an emerging bipartisan deal on Medicare clarifying that the agreement's abortion restrictions on community health centers are temporary and won't be inscribed into permanent law, House Democrats said Monday.

headline: Judge Rules Wisconsin Abortion Restriction Is Unconstitutional
paragraph: A federal judge on Friday struck down a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges.
text: Judge Rules Wisconsin Abortion Restriction Is Unconstitutional A federal judge on Friday struck down a state law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges.

abstract: People under 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports.
headline: Profiling the Distracted Driver: Young, Female and Solo
text: Profiling the Distracted Driver: Young, Female and Solo   People under 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports.

headline: Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew Remains Critically Ill in Intensive Care
paragraph: Singapore's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, remains critically ill in intensive care, the prime minister's office said on Thursday.
text: Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew Remains Critically Ill in Intensive Care Singapore's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, remains critically ill in intensive care, the prime minister's office said on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Justices to Hear Drunken Driving Victim's Medical Expenses Case
paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider whether a man injured by a drunken driver in Florida is required to pay more than $120,000 in medical costs back to his health plan administrator.
text: U.S. Justices to Hear Drunken Driving Victim's Medical Expenses Case The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider whether a man injured by a drunken driver in Florida is required to pay more than $120,000 in medical costs back to his health plan administrator.

abstract: Federal Judge William M Conley strikes down law in Wisconsin that requires doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges; rules women's health issues are substantially outweighed by harm done by restricting access to abortion.
headline: Wisconsin: Judge Strikes Abortion Law
paragraph: A federal judge on Friday struck down a Wisconsin law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges.
text: Wisconsin: Judge Strikes Abortion Law  A federal judge on Friday struck down a Wisconsin law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges. Federal Judge William M Conley strikes down law in Wisconsin that requires doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges; rules women's health issues are substantially outweighed by harm done by restricting access to abortion.

headline: Two More U.S. Healthcare Workers Repatriated for Ebola Monitoring
paragraph: The last two members of a group of U.S. healthcare workers whose colleague is being treated for the Ebola virus returned on Wednesday from Sierra Leone to the United States, where they are being monitored for possible exposure to the deadly virus.
text: Two More U.S. Healthcare Workers Repatriated for Ebola Monitoring The last two members of a group of U.S. healthcare workers whose colleague is being treated for the Ebola virus returned on Wednesday from Sierra Leone to the United States, where they are being monitored for possible exposure to the deadly virus.

headline: South Dakota Jury Finds Hospital Not Liable for 'KKK' Scars
paragraph: A federal jury has found that a South Dakota hospital is not liable in a case in which a man claimed health care workers carved the letters "KKK" into his stomach during heart surgery in 2011.

headline: Zimbabwe Officials Shoot Stray Dogs to Stop Rabies

headline: Serbian Nationalist Rebuffs Order to Return to War Crimes Court
paragraph: Serbian ultra-nationalist leader Vojislav Seselj rebuffed an order on Monday to return to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, which released him on health grounds in November.

headline: Indiana Governor to Declare Disaster for County Hit by HIV Outbreak
paragraph: Indiana Governor Mike Pence said on Wednesday he will declare a public health disaster in a small southern Indiana county that has seen a drastic increase in HIV cases tied to intravenous prescription drug abuse since December.
text: Indiana Governor to Declare Disaster for County Hit by HIV Outbreak Indiana Governor Mike Pence said on Wednesday he will declare a public health disaster in a small southern Indiana county that has seen a drastic increase in HIV cases tied to intravenous prescription drug abuse since December.

headline: Germanwings Crash Triggers Debate on Confidentiality Taboo
paragraph: Calls to relax Germany's strict doctor-patient confidentiality law after a Germanwings plane crash last week have touched a nerve in a country obsessed about privacy because of its authoritarian past.

headline: Spain to Reinstate Primary Healthcare for Illegal Immigrants

headline: Australia Mandates at Least 2 People Stay in Cockpits

abstract: Bus in northern Peru swerves into oncoming traffic on highway, causing multi-vehicle collision that leaves at least 37 people dead and 70 injured.
headline: Dozens Killed in Multi-Vehicle Crash in Peru
paragraph: At least 37 people were killed when a bus swerved into oncoming traffic in Peru on Monday, leading to a multi-vehicle collision involving two other buses and a freezer truck, the authorities said.

headline: Official: Ebola Survivor May Have Infected New Liberia Case

abstract: Pres Obama urges Congress to double funding to fight antibiotic resistance.

paragraph: A new plan was praised by some for seeking to curb antibiotic use in humans, but criticized by others for not doing enough to deal with its use in animals.
text: Obama Seeks to Double Funding to Fight Antibiotic Resistance A new plan was praised by some for seeking to curb antibiotic use in humans, but criticized by others for not doing enough to deal with its use in animals. Pres Obama urges Congress to double funding to fight antibiotic resistance.

headline: Ex-Doctor Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in Hepatitis Case
paragraph: A former prominent Las Vegas doctor already serving 18 years to life in state prison pleaded guilty Thursday to federal health care fraud and conspiracy charges in a hepatitis C outbreak that was called one of the largest ever in the U.S.
text: Ex-Doctor Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in Hepatitis Case A former prominent Las Vegas doctor already serving 18 years to life in state prison pleaded guilty Thursday to federal health care fraud and conspiracy charges in a hepatitis C outbreak that was called one of the largest ever in the U.S.

headline: Officials Urge Meningitis Shots at University of Oregon
paragraph: Public health officials Thursday issued a plea to parents of University of Oregon students to get their children vaccinated against meningitis after a sixth student has been found infected with the bacteria that can cause the potentially fatal disease.
text: Officials Urge Meningitis Shots at University of Oregon Public health officials Thursday issued a plea to parents of University of Oregon students to get their children vaccinated against meningitis after a sixth student has been found infected with the bacteria that can cause the potentially fatal disease.

abstract: Liberian woman is diagnosed with Ebola virus, dashing country's hope of being declared free of the disease.

paragraph: Confirmation that a patient tested positive deflated hope that Liberia was now free of the Ebola virus.
text: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks Confirmation that a patient tested positive deflated hope that Liberia was now free of the Ebola virus. Liberian woman is diagnosed with Ebola virus, dashing country's hope of being declared free of the disease.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Idaho in Medicaid Pay Dispute
paragraph: Private health care providers cannot sue to force states to raise their Medicaid reimbursement rates to keep up with rising medical costs, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.
text: Supreme Court Sides With Idaho in Medicaid Pay Dispute Private health care providers cannot sue to force states to raise their Medicaid reimbursement rates to keep up with rising medical costs, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.

headline: As Patients Face Death, Doctors Push Straight Talk on Care
paragraph: Dr. Angelo Volandes remembers performing rib-cracking CPR on a frail elderly man dying of lung cancer, a vivid example of an end-of-life dilemma: Because his patient never said if he wanted aggressive care as his body shut down, the hospital had to try. He died days later.
text: As Patients Face Death, Doctors Push Straight Talk on Care Dr. Angelo Volandes remembers performing rib-cracking CPR on a frail elderly man dying of lung cancer, a vivid example of an end-of-life dilemma: Because his patient never said if he wanted aggressive care as his body shut down, the hospital had to try. He died days later.

headline: Hospitals, Tax-Scofflaw Docs Targeted in House Medicare Deal
paragraph: House aides released an outline late Friday of an emerging bipartisan deal shielding physicians from Medicare cuts and pumping more funds to popular programs for children's health and community health centers.
text: Hospitals, Tax-Scofflaw Docs Targeted in House Medicare Deal House aides released an outline late Friday of an emerging bipartisan deal shielding physicians from Medicare cuts and pumping more funds to popular programs for children's health and community health centers.

headline: Indiana Governor Overrides Law to Authorize Needle Exchange
paragraph: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence overrode state law and his own anti-drug policies Thursday to authorize a short-term needle-exchange program designed to help contain HIV infections in a rural county where more than six dozen cases have been reported, all of them tied to intravenous drug use.
text: Indiana Governor Overrides Law to Authorize Needle Exchange Indiana Gov. Mike Pence overrode state law and his own anti-drug policies Thursday to authorize a short-term needle-exchange program designed to help contain HIV infections in a rural county where more than six dozen cases have been reported, all of them tied to intravenous drug use.

headline: U.S. House Okays Bipartisan Bill to Fix Medicare Doctor Payments
paragraph: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a bill to permanently repair the formula for reimbursing Medicare physicians, marking a rare bipartisan achievement and sending the issue next to the Senate.
text: U.S. House Okays Bipartisan Bill to Fix Medicare Doctor Payments The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a bill to permanently repair the formula for reimbursing Medicare physicians, marking a rare bipartisan achievement and sending the issue next to the Senate.

headline: House OKs Bipartisan Medicare Doctor Bill; Fate Up to Senate
paragraph: In uncommon bipartisan harmony, the House approved a $214 billion bill on Thursday permanently blocking physician Medicare cuts, moving Congress closer to resolving a problem that has plagued it for years.
text: House OKs Bipartisan Medicare Doctor Bill; Fate Up to Senate In uncommon bipartisan harmony, the House approved a $214 billion bill on Thursday permanently blocking physician Medicare cuts, moving Congress closer to resolving a problem that has plagued it for years.

abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column calls on Senate Democrats to abandon their opposition to plan created by Reps John Boehner and Nancy Pelosi that would fix formula for reimbursing doctors under Medicaire, issue that has threatened to become crisis; argues while Democratic objections to aspects of bill are legitimate, there comes a time to throw in ideological towel for the greater good.
headline: When Nancy Met Johnny
paragraph: When it comes to the ways of Washington, when should our elected representatives just make it happen?
text: When Nancy Met Johnny When it comes to the ways of Washington, when should our elected representatives just make it happen? headline: Police Shootings of Mentally Ill Reveal Gaps in Care
paragraph: A fatal shooting last year by police in Albuquerque, New Mexico, of a homeless man with a history of schizophrenia triggered large demonstrations. A month later, Milwaukee police shot a mentally ill man 14 times. In Dallas, a person with mental health problems that included bipolar disorder was killed by officers responding to a disturbance call, while another was seriously wounded in a separate shooting.

headline: GOP Moves Ahead on Budget Plans; Eyes Obamacare Repeal Bill
paragraph: House and Senate Republicans steamed ahead Tuesday toward likely approval of balanced budget outlines, essential early steps along a path to send President Barack Obama legislation to wipe out his five-year-old health care law and eliminate deficits within a decade.
