headline: White House Crafts First-Ever Plan to Fight Superbugs
paragraph: The White House is due to issue an ambitious plan to slow the growing and deadly problem of antibiotic resistance over the next five years, one that requires massive investments and policy changes from a broad array of U.S. government health agencies, according to a copy of the report reviewed by Reuters.
text: White House Crafts First-Ever Plan to Fight Superbugs The White House is due to issue an ambitious plan to slow the growing and deadly problem of antibiotic resistance over the next five years, one that requires massive investments and policy changes from a broad array of U.S. government health agencies, according to a copy of the report reviewed by Reuters.

headline: Liberia Urges Sexual Caution to Beat Ebola Outbreak

headline: Pfizer to Shutter Vaccines Sales Business in China

headline: Big Box Gyms May Be Fitter, When It Comes to Muscling Out Competition

headline: House, Senate GOP Budgets Have Differences and Similarities
paragraph: Republicans controlling the House and Senate have unveiled competing budget plans. But there are differences over defense and Medicare.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYLES, JEANNE EPSTEIN
paragraph:
EPSTEIN MYLES--Jeanne A.

M.D., died on March 26, 2015 at age 92. She was born in Jersey City, NJ, the daughter of Samuel and Ray Epstein. She received her B.S. from Douglass College and her M.D. from the Medical College of Pennsylvania. An endocrinologist, she was in practice with her husband, Martin B. Myles, M.D., and was a member of the clinical faculty of the NYU School of Medicine. She was also a staff physician at the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau. Later in her career she served as Medical Director of the Middletown Community Health Center in Middletown, NY. Survived by her beloved husband Martin and daughter Anne G. Myles and many loving nieces, nephews, and cousins, Jeanne was known by all as a highly intelligent, witty, and strong-minded woman. She was devoted to her family and friends and loved reading, nature, travel, fishing, and The New York Times crossword puzzle. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

Donations in her memory may be sent to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column examines American system for determining whether chemicals are safe, in light of finding by World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer that ingredient in herbicide Roundup may cause cancer; suggests Monsanto, which makes herbicide, should fund independent research to investigate claim, and that herbicide should be removed from market until research is completed.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN MYLES, JEANNE A. M.D.
paragraph: EPSTEIN MYLES--Jeanne A. M.D.,died on March 26, 2015 at age 92. She was born in Jersey City, NJ, the daughter of Samuel and Ray Epstein. She received her B.S. from Douglass College and her M.D. from the Medical College of Pennsylvania. An endocrinologist, she was in practice with her husband, Martin B. Myles, M.D., and was a member of the clinical faculty of the NYU School of Medicine. She was also a staff physician at the Margaret Sanger Research Bureau. Later in her career she served as Medical Director of the Middletown Community Health Center in Middletown, NY. Survived by her beloved husband Martin and daughter Anne G. Myles and many loving nieces, nephews, and cousins, Jeanne was known by all as a highly intelligent, witty, and strong-minded woman. She was devoted to her family and friends and loved reading, nature, travel, fishing, and The New York Times crossword puzzle. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. 1/3

abstract: Study published in JAMA Psychiatry, largest examination to date of climbing suicide rate among military personnel, finds no connection between suicide and deployment in support of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan; studies have been prompted by military suicide rate almost doubling since 2005.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, AZEN, ARYEH
paragraph: STEIN-AZEN--Aryeh, 24, passed away March 24 after living courageously with a rare form of sarcoma. A cum laude graduate of ChoateRosemary Hall and a member of the Princeton class of 2014, Aryeh was lauded by the Trustees of the University for "his exemplary academic performance, his exceptional contributions to the arts, his extraordinary courage, determination and persistence, and his devotion to Princeton." A Political Science major, his focus on Russian and Eurasian Studies included an interest in national security. Born in Philadelphia to Rabbi Margot Stein and Rabbi David Wechsler-Azen, he is survived by his parents and their spouses, Rabbi Myriam Klotz and Rabbi Nancy WechslerAzen, as well as his siblings Samm, Max, Eliza, Lily and Raffi, his grandparents Elaine and Bernie Roberts and Carol and Chuck Azen, and his beloved, Katy Dammers. Funeral services will take place on Thursday, March 26 at 1:00pm at B'nai Jeshurun, 257 W. 88th St., NY NY 10024. Contributions to provide integrated health support for students returning to Princeton with disabilities can be made to: The Trustees of Princeton University, with memo for The Aryeh Stein-Azen Fund, attn. Helen Hardy, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08540. May his memory always be for a blessing. 1/3

headline: Poll: Spend More, Tax Less, Legalize Pot
paragraph: Americans want lower taxes and more government spending both at once, although their support for spending more tax dollars on health care has dropped dramatically. They're likelier than ever to not feel connected to any particular religion, but no less likely to believe in God. And for the first time, most want to legalize marijuana.
text: Poll: Spend More, Tax Less, Legalize Pot Americans want lower taxes and more government spending both at once, although their support for spending more tax dollars on health care has dropped dramatically. They're likelier than ever to not feel connected to any particular religion, but no less likely to believe in God. And for the first time, most want to legalize marijuana.

abstract: Federal District Court in Brooklyn has been filled in recent years with Mafiosi on trial for crimes committed in 1970s and '80s, when Mafia loomed larger than it does today; informers are more common due to variety of factors, allowing prosecutors to pursue cases against people like Thomas DiFiore, highest-ranking member of Bonanno crime family; many defendants try to use age and infirmity in pleading for lenient sentencing.
headline: Before Judges, the Godfathers Become Sick Old Grandfathers
paragraph: A generation of geriatric gangsters known as the “oldfellas” can be found in court displaying catheter bags or discussing the state of their kidneys in hopes that a judge will agree to a short sentence.

headline: GOP-Controlled House Passes Budget to Erase Deficits

abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column examines extreme plight of children in Angola, deeply corrupt African nation with world's highest rate of child mortality; contends starvation, illness and death are all the more galling in light of Angola's oil and diamond wealth; holds West should do more to oppose Pres Jose Eduardo Dos Santos as he pillages his country and leaves children to die.
headline: Deadliest Country for Kids

headline: Correction: Seattle Minimum Wage Story
paragraph: In a story April 1 about Seattle's minimum wage law, The Associated Press erroneously reported the amount the small restaurant chain Skillet had raised wages. Skillet is phasing in a wage increase, as the law allows, not immediately increasing pay to $15 an hour.
text: Correction: Seattle Minimum Wage Story In a story April 1 about Seattle's minimum wage law, The Associated Press erroneously reported the amount the small restaurant chain Skillet had raised wages. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLE, STUART HALL
paragraph: BARTLE--Stuart Hall, 90, March 26, 2015. Son of Alice Hall Dowling and William A. Bartle. Survived by beloved wife of 65 years, Barbara (Sinclair) Bishop Bartle, half sister Ruth Dowling Bruun, children Chris (Eva Gardner), Andrew (Mary Davidson), Elizabeth (David Boghossian), Marion (John Packs), 11 grandchildren, many nieces and nephews. Educated at Pomfret School ('43), Harvard College (A.B. '50), NYU College of Medicine (M.D. '54). Stuart, aka "Poppy," "The Splendid Splinter" and "Dr. B," among other monikers, was especially fond of baseball, sailing, music, dancing and the fastest way to do things; was devoted to his wife, family, friends, colleagues and patients. A modest man, rarely spoke of his many accomplishments, known for his kindness, quick wit--trenchant and corny-- and enthusiasm. Served in the 78th Infantry Div. '43-'46 during the Battle of the Bulge and occupation of Berlin, awarded a Purple Heart and Bronze Star, among other medals. From 1959-67 participated in pioneering cardiology research at the University of Virginia, and in the civil rights movement in Charlottesville, VA. Resident in Psychiatry 1967-68, Mass. General Hospital. From 1968-86 practiced psychiatry in Manhattan, also attending and teaching at Mt. Sinai Hospital. From 1986-88, taught psychiatry in Harare, Zimbabwe, and from 1988-2012 served on the staff at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, MA in multiple positions, founding the Berkshire Mental Health Journal. Dr. B dedicated his professional life to humane and effective medical care, especially to treating the mentally ill with respect and dignity. Board service included Gould Farm, a residential therapeutic community, Austen Riggs Center, The Brien Center, and the Lower Eastside Service Center. Memorial Service: 3:00pm Saturday, April 18, Trinity Episcopal Church, Lenox, MA. Contributions in his name: Gould Farm, Monterey, MA, http://www.gouldfarm.org/. Thoughts at http://www.forevermissed. com/stuart-hall-bartle/ 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUICE, STUART UPCHURCH
paragraph: Buice--Stuart Upchurch, died on March 29, 2015, after a seven year journey with cancer. She is survived by her beloved husband of 50 years, William T. Buice, III, and her daughter, Merrill Stuart Buice and husband Jonathan Hubbard of San Francisco, and her son, Charles Upchurch Buice and wife Jenifer Buice of Brooklyn, NY, and by her grandchildren, Caroline and Wynant Hubbard and Meleana and Will Buice. She was born in Raleigh, NC, on December 1, 1942, the daughter of Theron Acriel Upchurch and Stuart Weatherspoon Upchurch and was educated at National Cathedral School, Duke University (B.A.) and New York University (M.A.). She was managing trustee of The Acriel Foundation for its 20 year history. It supported environmental, public health, cultural, and literary projects in North Carolina and along the East Coast. She was active in educational projects, including her service as a founding member of Duke University's Library Advisory Board and a trustee of Warren Wilson College, the Shelter Island Educational Foundation, and Grace Church School (NYC); and in civic affairs as a member of the boards of the Women's City Club (NYC), The Cosmopolitan Club (NYC), and The Shelter Island Heights Property Owners Corp. Stuart was active in the Grolier Club (NYC), Rare Book School (Univ. of Virginia.), The North Carolina Society of NY, the New York Junior League, and The Wednesday Club. A long-time member of The First Presbyterian Church (NYC), she served as a ruling elder, chair of its Nursery School board and co-chair of two of its capital campaigns. She was grateful to her oncological teams at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital (NYC) and The Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. In lieu of flowers, tax deductible contributions may be made to The First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12th Street, New York, NY, 10011, for its Sanctuary Lighting Fund, or to The Shelter Island Public Library, P.O. Box 2016, Shelter Island, NY, 11964. A memorial service in celebration of her life will be held at 11:00 a.m. on Saturday, April 11, 2015, at The First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at 12th Street, NYC.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLE, STUART
paragraph:
BARTLE--Stuart Hall,

90, March 26, 2015. Son of Alice Hall Dowling and William A. Bartle. Survived by beloved wife of 65 years, Barbara (Sinclair) Bishop Bartle, half sister Ruth Dowling Bruun, children Chris (Eva Gardner), Andrew (Mary Davidson), Elizabeth (David Boghossian), Marion (John Packs), 11 grandchildren, many nieces and nephews. Educated at Pomfret School ('43), Harvard College (A.B. '50), NYU College of Medicine (M.D. '54). Stuart, aka "Poppy," "The Splendid Splinter" and "Dr. B," among other monikers, was especially fond of baseball, sailing, music, dancing and the fastest way to do things; was devoted to his wife, family, friends, colleagues and patients. A modest man, rarely spoke of his many accomplishments, known for his kindness, quick wit--trenchant and corny-- and enthusiasm. Served in the 78th Infantry Div. '43-'46 during the Battle of the Bulge and occupation of Berlin, awarded a Purple Heart and Bronze Star, among other medals. From 1959-67 participated in pioneering cardiology research at the University of Virginia, and in the civil rights movement in Charlottesville, VA. Resident in Psychiatry 1967-68, Mass. General Hospital. From 1968-86 practiced psychiatry in Manhattan, also attending and teaching at Mt. Sinai Hospital. From 1986-88, taught psychiatry in Harare, Zimbabwe, and from 1988-2012 served on the staff at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, MA in multiple positions, founding the Berkshire Mental Health Journal. Dr. B dedicated his professional life to humane and effective medical care, especially to treating the mentally ill with respect and dignity. Board service included Gould Farm, a residential therapeutic community, Austen Riggs Center, The Brien Center, and the Lower Eastside Service Center. Memorial Service: 3:00pm Saturday, April 18, Trinity Episcopal Church, Lenox, MA. Contributions in his name: Gould Farm, Monterey, MA, http://www.gouldfarm.org/ Thoughts at http://www.forevermissed com/stuart-hall-bartle/

headline: Pelosi Irks Some Allies Over Bipartisan Bill With Boehner
paragraph: House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi bruised some longtime liberal allies when she worked with Speaker John Boehner to craft a rare bipartisan accord on Medicare. But lawmakers say it will enhance her stature as a dealmaker, and may help her party avoid being sidelined by majority Republicans over the next two years.

abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column examines rampant corruption and graft in Angola that has become a major factor in malnutrition and child corruption; holds corruption, like the worms that infect so many of nation's children, has deeply parasitical effect; castigates Western oil companies and banks that work closely with Angolan officials, enabling kleptocracy; calls for greater transparency and pressure on leaders to use funds for good.
headline: An Unsettling Complicity
paragraph: It’s not a coincidence that Angola is a center for malnutrition and child mortality as well as rampant corruption.
text: An Unsettling Complicity It’s not a coincidence that Angola is a center for malnutrition and child mortality as well as rampant corruption. Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column examines rampant corruption and graft in Angola that has become a major factor in malnutrition and child corruption; holds corruption, like the worms that infect so many of nation's children, has deeply parasitical effect; castigates Western oil companies and banks that work closely with Angolan officials, enabling kleptocracy; calls for greater transparency and pressure on leaders to use funds for good.

headline: Cruz Becomes First Major Candidate to Jump Into 2016 Race
paragraph: Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz has become the first major candidate for president, kicking off what's expected to be a rush over the next few weeks of more than a dozen White House hopefuls into the 2016 campaign.

headline: Justices Seem Divided Over EPA Mercury Limits
paragraph: The Supreme Court's conservative justices cast doubt Wednesday on the Obama administration's first-ever regulations aimed at reducing power plant emissions of mercury and other hazardous air pollutants that contribute to respiratory illnesses, birth defects and developmental problems in children.
text: Justices Seem Divided Over EPA Mercury Limits The Supreme Court's conservative justices cast doubt Wednesday on the Obama administration's first-ever regulations aimed at reducing power plant emissions of mercury and other hazardous air pollutants that contribute to respiratory illnesses, birth defects and developmental problems in children.

headline: German Co-Pilot Was Once Treated for Suicidal Tendencies
paragraph: How could someone once diagnosed with suicidal tendencies get a job as a commercial pilot, entrusted with the lives of hundreds of people? That's the question being asked after officials confirmed Monday that Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz received lengthy psychotherapy before receiving his pilot's license.
text: German Co-Pilot Was Once Treated for Suicidal Tendencies How could someone once diagnosed with suicidal tendencies get a job as a commercial pilot, entrusted with the lives of hundreds of people? abstract: Charles M Blow Op-Ed column examines failures of Louisiana Gov Bobby Jindal, who has gone from being one of most popular governors in country to one of least popular, squandering his presidential chances in process; maintains Jindal struck promising and intelligent figure when he first appeared on national scene in 2009, but has since shamed himself with dysfunctional policies, budget fiascoes and xenophobia.

abstract: Tunisian authorities spend day evacuating dead and wounded foreign tourists and burying Tunisian dead in aftermath of terrorist attack on National Bardo Museum in Tunis, which killed 23 people; Pres Beji Caid Essebsi says in Independence Day speech that Islamic State group claimed responsibility and that security forces believe claim to be true.

headline: Feds: Baltimore Jail Illegally Keeping Juveniles in Solitary
paragraph: Teenagers awaiting trial on adult charges in Baltimore are being kept in solitary confinement for far too long — up to 143 days in one case, according to a highly critical review by the U.S. Justice Department's Division of Civil Rights.

headline: U.S. Sets First Major Fracking Rules on Federal Lands
paragraph: The Obama administration's new rules governing fracking on federal lands drew swift criticism from all sides on Friday, with green groups calling the measures "toothless" and the energy industry slamming "unnecessary" regulation of a drilling process that has brought the United States to the cusp of oil and gas self-sufficiency.

abstract: Study published in journal Lancet Infectious Diseases finds that strain of common respiratory virus known as enterovirus 68 may be responsible for partially paralyzing more than 100 children nationwide since August 2014.
headline: Enterovirus 68 May Be Linked to Paralysis in Children, Study Says

headline: Co-Pilot Appeared Healthy, but May Have Hidden Illness
paragraph: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz appeared happy and healthy to acquaintances, but a picture emerged Friday of a man who hid evidence of an illness from his employers — including a torn-up doctor's note that would have kept him off work the day authorities say he crashed Flight 9525 into an Alpine mountainside.

abstract: Melinda Gates essay examines gender gap in spread of digital financial services to world's poorest regions; holds that a vision of connecting more than two billion people to their first bank accounts cannot materialize without ensuring that such services reach women, an especially critical factor in the success of developing economies.

headline: Cruz's Fiery Message Has Limited Appeal to Some in GOP
paragraph: Ted Cruz gives a rousing speech. The former college debate champion can energize a crowd of 10,000 evangelicals at a basketball arena as easily as he can captivate a few dozen inside a New Hampshire cafeteria. He's proven in the Senate he's got the stamina to go on longer than anyone else to make his point.

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Elizabeth Currid-Halkett calls on women who are able to produce excess breast milk and who have the time and resources to donate their milk to milk banks; suggests ways to encourage breast milk donation, such as provision of free breast pumps and storage banks by philanthropic organizations, as well as public-awareness campaigns about milk donation.

paragraph: Donating breast milk should be more like donating blood.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column warns Republican-proposed budget represents new height in fiscal dishonesty; says promise of huge cuts in spending and revenue increases without explaining where money will come from is trend specific to new breed of Republican lawmakers; says budget would result in large transfer of income from poor and working class to rich and would leave United States several trillion dollars deeper in debt.

headline: House Republicans Vow to Close Ranks, Support Budget Plan

headline: Fed Vice Chair Fischer: Rate Hike Is Likely This Year
paragraph: Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer says he expects the Fed to start raising interest rates sometime this year. Once that happens, though, rates won't likely move in any predictable pattern, he added.
text: Fed Vice Chair Fischer: Rate Hike Is Likely This Year Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer says he expects the Fed to start raising interest rates sometime this year. Once that happens, though, rates won't likely move in any predictable pattern, he added.

headline: North Dakota Launches Oil Rules Hoping to Curb U.S. Rail Disasters
paragraph: North Dakota will from Wednesday require the more-than 1.2 million barrels of crude extracted each day from the state's Bakken shale formation be run through machines that remove volatile gases linked to recent crude-by-rail disasters.

abstract: Odd tax credit for buyers of luxury boats emerges as one of thousands of items packed into New York State Gov Andrew M Cuomo's $150 billion budget; tax break stipulates that buyers of boats valued at more than $230,000 will not have to pay sales tax beyond that amount, regardless of price; proponents argue that clause will create jobs.

headline: Tunisian Army to Increase Security After Museum Attack
paragraph: Tunisia said it would deploy the army to major cities and arrested four people on Thursday after militant gunmen killed 20 foreign tourists visiting the national Bardo museum, the worst attack on the north African country in more than a decade.

headline: 3 West African Countries Increase Fight to End Ebola

headline: Cuba, US to Launch Human Rights Dialogue Tuesday

abstract: Editorial holds damning report on state of New York City's homeless shelters reveals systemic collapse; contends inspection system has become meaningless, and city continues to pay millions to house homeless in places that are known to be dangerous and squalid; calls on Homeless Services Dept to work with other city agencies to insure that all of its 145 shelters are brought up to code.

headline: Surgery and Sterilization Scrapped in Malta's Benchmark LGBTI Law
paragraph: Transgender people in Malta will no longer need to have surgery, sterilization and a diagnosis of mental illness to legally change gender under a law passed on Wednesday, which rights groups hailed as a new benchmark for LGBTI rights in Europe.
text: Surgery and Sterilization Scrapped in Malta's Benchmark LGBTI Law Transgender people in Malta will no longer need to have surgery, sterilization and a diagnosis of mental illness to legally change gender under a law passed on Wednesday, which rights groups hailed as a new benchmark for LGBTI rights in Europe.

abstract: Chirlane McCray, wife of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, remains an influential voice in her husband's policy decisions, though she has not been nearly as involved in day-to-day operations as her detractors initially feared; McCray has instead chosen to focus on handful of issues that she relates to personally, overseeing review of city's mental health issues and emerging as public face of de Blasio's education initiatives.

headline: Lawmakers Urge More Study of US Tribal Recognition Changes

text: Lawmakers Urge More Study of US Tribal Recognition Changes Several congressional members called on the U.S. Interior Department Thursday to slow down an overhaul of the rules for granting federal recognition to American Indian tribes, saying more study is needed of problems that could result from lowering the bar for the coveted status.

headline: U.S. House Republicans Face Test of Unity in Budget Votes

headline: New Research Says Anne Frank Likely Died a Month Earlier
paragraph: Teenage Jewish diarist Anne Frank likely died of typhus in a Nazi concentration camp about a month earlier than previously thought, the Amsterdam museum that honors her memory said Tuesday on the 70th anniversary of the officially recognized date of her death.
text: New Research Says Anne Frank Likely Died a Month Earlier Teenage Jewish diarist Anne Frank likely died of typhus in a Nazi concentration camp about a month earlier than previously thought, the Amsterdam museum that honors her memory said Tuesday on the 70th anniversary of the officially recognized date of her death.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZE, MORGAN CHUAN, YUAN
paragraph: SZE--Morgan Chuan-Yuan, 98, died at home in Portsmouth, NH on March 20, 2015 after a period of declining health. He was born on May 27,1916 (mistakenly listed as 1917 when he entered this country) in Tianjin, China, son of S.C. Thomas Sze, a 1905 Cornell educated engineer, and Elsie Sun Sze. He graduated from the Peking American School as valedictorian in 1935 and entered Tsinghua University in Beijing but was unable to complete his studies there because of political unrest. He transferred to M.I.T. in 1937, receiving his B.S. in 1939 and doctorate in 1941, both in chemical engineering. An internationally recognized engineer, he spent time at DuPont, Hydrocarbon Research, Lummus, where he rose to V.P. of Research and Development, and Wheelabrator-Frye. He was the author of numerous scientific papers and holder of some 80 U.S. patents. Honors included a 1969 award by the Chinese Institute of Engineers in recognition of outstanding contributions to chemical processes and Chemical Engineering magazine's Personal Achievement Award in 1976. That same year he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering, one of the highest professional honors accorded an engineer. He had an enduring belief in the role of science and technology for the betterment of individuals' lives and society as a whole. Morgan had a firm belief that a broad and deep education offered one the best opportunity for a successful life and that knowledge in one field could lead to insights or discoveries in another. He was deeply appreciative of the opportunity to start a new life in his adoptive country and greatly valued his American citizenship. He had a deep sense of responsibility and cared for many extended family members who came to this country as refugees. Morgan was a true gentleman and will be greatly missed by his longtime neighbors, his caregivers and his extended family. He was predeceased by his wife, Agnes, and his siblings, Gladys Sun, Dorothy Liu, Palmer and Y.Y. Sze. He is survived by sons, Karl and wife Kay of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, Arthur and wife Carol of Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Morgan C.W. and wife Bobbi of Hong Kong, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the M.I.T. Memorial Undergraduate Scholarship Fund in memory of Dr. Morgan C. Sze at: M.I.T. Director of Memorial Gifts, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZE, MORGAN
paragraph:
SZE--Morgan Chuan-Yuan,

98, died at home in Portsmouth, NH on March 20, 2015 after a period of declining health. He was born on May 27,1916 (mistakenly listed as 1917 when he entered this country) in Tianjin, China, son of S.C. Thomas Sze, a 1905 Cornell educated engineer, and Elsie Sun Sze. He graduated from the Peking American School as valedictorian in 1935 and entered Tsinghua University in Beijing but was unable to complete his studies there because of political unrest. He transferred to M.I.T. in 1937, receiving his B.S. in 1939 and doctorate in 1941, both in chemical engineering. An internationally recognized engineer, he spent time at DuPont, Hydrocarbon Research, Lummus, where he rose to V.P. of Research and Development, and Wheelabrator-Frye. He was the author of numerous scientific papers and holder of some 80 U.S. patents. Honors included a 1969 award by the Chinese Institute of Engineers in recognition of outstanding contributions to chemical processes and Chemical Engineering magazine's Personal Achievement Award in 1976. That same year he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering, one of the highest professional honors accorded an engineer. He had an enduring belief in the role of science and technology for the betterment of individuals' lives and society as a whole. Morgan had a firm belief that a broad and deep education offered one the best opportunity for a successful life and that knowledge in one field could lead to insights or discoveries in another. He was deeply appreciative of the opportunity to start a new life in his adoptive country and greatly valued his American citizenship. He had a deep sense of responsibility and cared for many extended family members who came to this country as refugees. Morgan was a true gentleman and will be greatly missed by his longtime neighbors, his caregivers and his extended family. He was predeceased by his wife, Agnes, and his siblings, Gladys Sun, Dorothy Liu, Palmer and Y.Y. Sze. He is survived by sons, Karl and wife Kay of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, Arthur and wife Carol of Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Morgan C.W. and wife Bobbi of Hong Kong, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the M.I.T. Memorial Undergraduate Scholarship Fund in memory of Dr. Morgan C. Sze at: M.I.T. Director of Memorial Gifts, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139.

headline: Obama Calls on Iran to Immediately Release Detained Americans
paragraph: U.S. President Barack Obama on Friday called on Iran's government to immediately release three detained Americans - Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmati and Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian - and to help find Robert Levinson, an American who disappeared in Iran eight years ago, the White House said.

headline: Thailand Jails Brothers of Former Princess for Five-And-a-Half Years

paragraph: At their annual round table, the N.F.L.’s coaches stayed true to form. Belichick gave short answers. Rex Ryan offered bluster. The Jets’ new coach, Todd Bowles, was eager to get going.
text: A Few Words From Bill Belichick After a Super Bowl Win. Very Few. At their annual round table, the N.F.L.’s coaches stayed true to form. Belichick gave short answers. Rex Ryan offered bluster. The Jets’ new coach, Todd Bowles, was eager to get going. New England Patriots coach Bill Belichick gives characteristically minimalist answers to reporters' questions at coaches’ round table at NFL owners' meeting; New York Jets accuse Patriots of tampering over comments made by owner Robert K Kraft; owners approve five rule changes to help prevent injuries.

abstract: Lawsuit by child advocacy groups alleges that Arizona's child welfare system routinely removes children from unstable families only to place them in worse circumstances and that state has been slow to reform foster care system; suit resulted in ouster of Charles Flanagan as director of Dept of Child Safety and installation of his replacement Gregory McKay, police officer who blew whistle on system's failings.
headline: As Arizona Struggles to Fix Foster System, Children Suffer the Consequences
paragraph: Two advocacy groups that filed a lawsuit last month against the state say children are being rescued from one bad situation only to end up in another one.
text: As Arizona Struggles to Fix Foster System, Children Suffer the Consequences Two advocacy groups that filed a lawsuit last month against the state say children are being rescued from one bad situation only to end up in another one. Lawsuit by child advocacy groups alleges that Arizona's child welfare system routinely removes children from unstable families only to place them in worse circumstances and that state has been slow to reform foster care system; suit resulted in ouster of Charles Flanagan as director of Dept of Child Safety and installation of his replacement Gregory McKay, police officer who blew whistle on system's failings.

headline: Science, Patients Driving Rare Disease Drug Research Surge
paragraph: The global pharmaceutical industry is pouring billions of dollars into developing treatments for rare diseases, which once drew little interest from major drugmakers but now point the way toward a new era of innovative therapies and big profits.
text: Science, Patients Driving Rare Disease Drug Research Surge The global pharmaceutical industry is pouring billions of dollars into developing treatments for rare diseases, which once drew little interest from major drugmakers but now point the way toward a new era of innovative therapies and big profits.

abstract: Concerns grow in Liberia over number of people who may have been exposed to country's first Ebola case in more than two weeks; patient lived in one-bathroom house with 52 others and sold food at school attended by nearly 2,000 students.
headline: Exposure Concerns Grow in Liberia After Diagnosis of First Ebola Case in Weeks
paragraph: The patient, a street vendor who lived in a one-bathroom house shared with 52 others in a Monrovia suburb, had sold food last week at a school where more than 1,900 students are enrolled.
text: Exposure Concerns Grow in Liberia After Diagnosis of First Ebola Case in Weeks The patient, a street vendor who lived in a one-bathroom house shared with 52 others in a Monrovia suburb, had sold food last week at a school where more than 1,900 students are enrolled. Concerns grow in Liberia over number of people who may have been exposed to country's first Ebola case in more than two weeks; patient lived in one-bathroom house with 52 others and sold food at school attended by nearly 2,000 students.

headline: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Tunisia Attack
paragraph: The Islamic State group claimed responsibility Thursday for the attack that killed 21 people at a museum. But Tunisian authorities said the two slain gunmen had no clear links to extremists, and analysts said existing militant cells are merely being inspired by the group, rather than establishing its presence across North Africa.
text: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Tunisia Attack The Islamic State group claimed responsibility Thursday for the attack that killed 21 people at a museum. But Tunisian authorities said the two slain gunmen had no clear links to extremists, and analysts said existing militant cells are merely being inspired by the group, rather than establishing its presence across North Africa.

abstract: House Republicans narrowly approve budget that increases military spending, but cuts domestic programs and starts to privatize Medicare; plan is to shrink government spending $5.5 trillion over next ten years.
headline: Increased Military Spending Wins Out After Dueling Budget Votes in House
paragraph: Republicans framed the debate around the imperative to shrink the government’s reach, balance the budget and begin to pay down the federal debt — without raising taxes.
text: Increased Military Spending Wins Out After Dueling Budget Votes in House Republicans framed the debate around the imperative to shrink the government’s reach, balance the budget and begin to pay down the federal debt — without raising taxes. House Republicans narrowly approve budget that increases military spending, but cuts domestic programs and starts to privatize Medicare; plan is to shrink government spending $5.5 trillion over next ten years.

abstract: News Analysis; some Midwestern states are rolling back collective bargaining rights for government workers, including pensions and health coverage, but excluding police and firefighters; labor experts say exemptions have no substantive merit, as other public workers have much more dangerous jobs.
headline: Public Pension Cuts Exempt Police and Firefighters
paragraph: Recent labor legislation, such as measures to curb collective bargaining and change pensions and health coverage, often exempts public safety workers.

abstract: The Upshot; 114th Congress's handling of budget resolution is likely to answer questions about Republican majority's ability to govern, three months into its term; process has already exposed tensions within Republican caucus, many of them rooted in disagreements about whether to challenge Pres Obama or to lay groundwork for Republican wave in 2016 election.
headline: Why Congress Is Having Trouble Governing
paragraph: The budget resolution process is exposing rifts within the Republican Party.

abstract: News Analysis; Marc Mauer, director of Sentencing Project, proposed to congressional task force on reforming prison system that prison sentences should be capped at 20 years, with option for adding time if prisoners are deemed dangerous; proposal is unlikely to be adopted, but its efficacy has been bolstered by research that many older criminals are less likely to commit crimes.
headline: Too Old to Commit Crime?
paragraph: Research shows that most criminals, even violent ones, mature out of lawbreaking before middle age, suggesting long sentences do little to prevent crime.
text: Too Old to Commit Crime? Research shows that most criminals, even violent ones, mature out of lawbreaking before middle age, suggesting long sentences do little to prevent crime. abstract: New York Mets beat New York Yankees, 6-0, in spring training exhibition game.
headline: From First Inning, Yankees and Jose Pirela Are Rattled by the Mets
paragraph: Pirela crashed into the center-field wall, allowing the Mets’ leadoff hitter in the first inning to score, and was taken to the hospital as the Mets beat the Yankees, 6-0, in spring training.
text: From First Inning, Yankees and Jose Pirela Are Rattled by the Mets Pirela crashed into the center-field wall, allowing the Mets’ leadoff hitter in the first inning to score, and was taken to the hospital as the Mets beat the Yankees, 6-0, in spring training. New York Mets beat New York Yankees, 6-0, in spring training exhibition game.

abstract: Sen Robert Menendez of New Jersey is indicted on federal bribery charges, first such charges against a sitting senator in a generation; is also charged with conspiracy; accusations lodged against Menendez, which include trading political favors for luxury gifts and campaign donations, are more extensive than what was publicly known.
headline: Senator Robert Menendez Indicted on Corruption Charges
paragraph: Mr. Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, who prosecutors say traded political favors for vacations, campaign donations and flights, angrily denied wrongdoing and vowed to fight.
text: Senator Robert Menendez Indicted on Corruption Charges Mr. Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, who prosecutors say traded political favors for vacations, campaign donations and flights, angrily denied wrongdoing and vowed to fight. Sen Robert Menendez of New Jersey is indicted on federal bribery charges, first such charges against a sitting senator in a generation; is also charged with conspiracy; accusations lodged against Menendez, which include trading political favors for luxury gifts and campaign donations, are more extensive than what was publicly known.

abstract: Sen Harry Reid of Nevada announces that he will retire from Senate in 2016, bringing end to three-decade congressional career.

paragraph: The senator from Nevada, a tactician who has led Senate Democrats since 2005, said he had been contemplating retiring for months.

abstract: Profile of Andreas Lubitz, German co-pilot who French officials say deliberately caused crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, killing himself and 149 other people; records indicate Lubitz had passed all medical and flying tests, and reveal few signs that he had become troubled or disturbed; associates describe him as cheerful and professionally careful.
headline: Andreas Lubitz, Who Loved to Fly, Ended Up on a Mysterious and Deadly Course
paragraph: The co-pilot accused of deliberately crashing a plane into the Alps passed all medical and flying tests, Lufthansa officials said.

headline: High Nursing Home Bills Squeeze Insurers, Driving Rates Up
paragraph: Thirty years ago, insurance companies had the answer to the soaring cost of caring for the elderly. Plan ahead and buy a policy that will cover your expenses.

headline: Scientists Say Polar Bears Won't Thrive on Land Food
paragraph: A group of researchers say polar bears forced off melting sea ice will not find enough food to replace their current diet of fat-laden marine mammals such as seals, a conclusion that contradicts studies indicating that bears may be benefiting from bird eggs, berries and other land food sources.
text: Scientists Say Polar Bears Won't Thrive on Land Food A group of researchers say polar bears forced off melting sea ice will not find enough food to replace their current diet of fat-laden marine mammals such as seals, a conclusion that contradicts studies indicating that bears may be benefiting from bird eggs, berries and other land food sources.

headline: Alps Crash: Bodies Recovered, but Families Must Wait Months
paragraph: Just over a week after a Germanwings plane crashed into the French Alps, investigators have finished retrieving human remains from the crash site and are now trying to match them with DNA profiles from the 150 people killed — an arduous task that could leave families waiting for months.
text: Alps Crash: Bodies Recovered, but Families Must Wait Months Just over a week after a Germanwings plane crashed into the French Alps, investigators have finished retrieving human remains from the crash site and are now trying to match them with DNA profiles from the 150 people killed — an arduous task that could leave families waiting for months.

headline: Cancer Experts Laud Angelina Jolie's Decision to Remove Ovaries
paragraph: Two years after a double mastectomy, actress Angelina Jolie has had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed to avoid the risk of ovarian cancer, a move cancer experts described as courageous and influential.
text: Cancer Experts Laud Angelina Jolie's Decision to Remove Ovaries Two years after a double mastectomy, actress Angelina Jolie has had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed to avoid the risk of ovarian cancer, a move cancer experts described as courageous and influential.

headline: Modi's Popularity in Rural India Punctured by Discontent, Suicides
paragraph: Over a dozen debt-laden farmers have committed suicide in recent weeks in India, and discontent in many rural areas against government policies is turning into anger against Prime Minister Narendra Modi less than a year after he swept into office.
text: Modi's Popularity in Rural India Punctured by Discontent, Suicides Over a dozen debt-laden farmers have committed suicide in recent weeks in India, and discontent in many rural areas against government policies is turning into anger against Prime Minister Narendra Modi less than a year after he swept into office.

abstract: Journalist David Brancaccio suggests personal finances should include consulting one's future self about the impact of major financial decisions; notes behavioral economists caution against so-called hyperbolic discounting, or seeking immediate gratification rather than waiting for a larger financial payoff later.
headline: Need Financial Advice? Ask the Future You
paragraph: In personal finances, it’s easy to focus too much on the present. To overcome this, think of yourself and your needs years from now.
text: Need Financial Advice? Ask the Future You In personal finances, it’s easy to focus too much on the present. To overcome this, think of yourself and your needs years from now. Journalist David Brancaccio suggests personal finances should include consulting one's future self about the impact of major financial decisions; notes behavioral economists caution against so-called hyperbolic discounting, or seeking immediate gratification rather than waiting for a larger financial payoff later.

abstract: Supreme Court appears split in case over whether Environmental Protection Agency violated Clean Air Act; lawyers for industry groups and 20 states say EPA rules setting limits on power plant emissions did not consider high costs they would cause; agency did not undertake cost-benefit analysis.
headline: Supreme Court Seems Split on What Is ‘Appropriate’ in Setting Clean Air Costs
paragraph: Lawyers for industry groups and some 20 states told the justices that Environmental Protection Agency regulations that set limits on emissions from power plants had failed to take account of the punishing costs they would impose.
text: Supreme Court Seems Split on What Is ‘Appropriate’ in Setting Clean Air Costs Lawyers for industry groups and some 20 states told the justices that Environmental Protection Agency regulations that set limits on emissions from power plants had failed to take account of the punishing costs they would impose. Supreme Court appears split in case over whether Environmental Protection Agency violated Clean Air Act; lawyers for industry groups and 20 states say EPA rules setting limits on power plant emissions did not consider high costs they would cause; agency did not undertake cost-benefit analysis.

headline: California First to Feel Hydro-Power Crunch of Drought
paragraph: Flying over the Sierra Nevada as California entered its fourth year of drought, the state's energy chief looked down and saw stark bare granite cloaked in dirty brown haze — not the usual pristine white peaks heaped with snow that would run the state's hydroelectric dams for the year.
text: California First to Feel Hydro-Power Crunch of Drought Flying over the Sierra Nevada as California entered its fourth year of drought, the state's energy chief looked down and saw stark bare granite cloaked in dirty brown haze — not the usual pristine white peaks heaped with snow that would run the state's hydroelectric dams for the year.

abstract: Obama administration unveils nation's first major federal regulations for hydraulic fracturing, to take effect in 90 days; hope is that federal rules will serve as model for state legislatures grappling with their own well-drilling regulations, many of which are technologically far out of date.
headline: New Federal Rules Are Set for Fracking
paragraph: The Interior Department began drafting the rules during President Obama’s first term after the technology led to a surge in the production of oil and gas.
text: New Federal Rules Are Set for Fracking The Interior Department began drafting the rules during President Obama’s first term after the technology led to a surge in the production of oil and gas. Obama administration unveils nation's first major federal regulations for hydraulic fracturing, to take effect in 90 days; hope is that federal rules will serve as model for state legislatures grappling with their own well-drilling regulations, many of which are technologically far out of date.

text: Weak Economic Reports Lead Market to Second Day of Losses Indexes declined, extending losses from a day earlier as discouraging economic reports on manufacturing, jobs and construction spending stoked investor concerns. paragraph: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled that the U.S. central bank will likely start raising borrowing costs later this year, even before inflation and wages have returned to health, but emphasized the return to normal interest rates will be gradual.
text: Fed's Yellen Sees Gradual Rate Hikes Starting This Year Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled that the U.S. central bank will likely start raising borrowing costs later this year, even before inflation and wages have returned to health, but emphasized the return to normal interest rates will be gradual.

headline: Japan Uses Climate Cash for Coal Plants in India, Bangladesh

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, FRANCIS
paragraph:
ROONEY--Francis C.

Francis C. Rooney, Jr., the Chairman of H.H. Brown Shoe Company and the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Melville Corporation, died on March 24, 2015 at Greenwich Hospital. He was 93 years old. Rooney was married for 65 years to the love of his life, the former Frances Heffernan of Worcester, Massachusetts. One of the leading retail executives of his generation, Rooney transformed Melville Corporation from a shoe company with $180 million in revenue at the time he became chief executive officer at age 42 into a specialty retail business with over $7 billion of revenue at the time of his retirement in 1987. In 1987, Melville's businesses included Marshall's, Linens & Things, K.B. Toys and CVS Drug Stores. Today the company's name has changed from Melville Corp to CVS Health Corporation. In 1990, after three years of retirement, Rooney agreed to become CEO of H.H. Brown Shoe Co., Inc., which was owned by his late father-in -law. In 1991, the company was sold to Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and at Warren Buffett?s request he became Chairman. In a press interview, Mr. Buffett concluded, Frank "is a sensational human being and a great manager." Throughout his adult life Rooney maintained a commitment to numerous civic, charitable and education causes. He was one of the founding trustees of the Inner City Scholarship Fund, which today provides over 30,000 inner city children with scholarships to attend Catholic schools in New York City. He also served as a trustee of United Cerebral Palsy; Greenwich Hospital; March of Dimes; Smithsonian Institute; Boys & Girls Club of America; St. Ignatius School in the Bronx; The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania; Pace University; and Fordham University. In 1987, Rooney received an honorary degree from Boston College. In addition, Rooney served on the Board of Directors of Bankers Trust Company; Collins & Aikman Textile Company; ADT; AMF Corporation; Black & Decker; Dunkin Donuts; and Neiman Markus. Frank Rooney was born at home in North Brookfield, Massachusetts on Thanksgiving Day, November 24, 1921. He graduated in 1939 from North Brookfield High School where he was captain of the basketball team, and he received his bachelor degree from the University of Pennsylvania (Wharton School) in 1943. He graduated as an Ensign in the U.S. Naval Reserve and was assigned that year to the battleship USS North Carolina in the Pacific. He was aboard as a gunnery officer in 10 major engagements between 1943 and 1945. He began his business career in 1946 as a sales trainee with the John Foote Shoe Company in Brockton, Massachusetts. Two years later, he went to work for the Florsheim Shoe Company in Chicago, and in 1953 he joined the Thom McAn Shoe Company, a subsidiary of Melville Shoe Corporation, as a buyer/ stylist. He rose to President of Thom McAn in 1961 and in 1964 he was elected Chairman, President and CEO of Melville Shoe Corporation. Mr. Rooney is survived by his beloved wife Frances Heffernan and eight children: Peter M. Rooney (Kathy) of Basking Ridge, NJ; Michael F. Rooney (Joann) of New Rochelle, NY; Stephen G. Rooney (Susan) of Pelham Manor, NY; Jean R. Weil (Jerry) of Greenwich, CT; William A. Rooney (Amy) of Charlotte, NC; Carol R. Flanagan (James) of Greenwich, CT; Frances R. Cifrino (Michael) of Hingham, MA and Clare R. Butler (David) of Harrison, NY, as well as 27 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Mr. Rooney was an avid golfer and a long time member of Blind Brook Golf Club, Winged Foot Golf Club, Ekwanok Golf Club, Sankaty Head Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, Lyford Cay Club and Lost Tree Club. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Friday from 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection on Saturday at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund. For information go to innercityscholarshipfund.org.

In 1990, after three years of retirement, Rooney agreed to become CEO of H.H. Brown Shoe Co., Inc., which was owned by his late father-in -law. Two years later, he went to work for the Florsheim Shoe Company in Chicago, and in 1953 he joined the Thom McAn Shoe Company, a subsidiary of Melville Shoe Corporation, as a buyer/ stylist. He rose to President of Thom McAn in 1961 and in 1964 he was elected Chairman, President and CEO of Melville Shoe Corporation. Mr. Rooney is survived by his beloved wife Frances Heffernan and eight children: Peter M. Rooney (Kathy) of Basking Ridge, NJ; Michael F. Rooney (Joann) of New Rochelle, NY; Stephen G. Rooney (Susan) of Pelham Manor, NY; Jean R. Weil (Jerry) of Greenwich, CT; William A. Rooney (Amy) of Charlotte, NC; Carol R. Flanagan (James) of Greenwich, CT; Frances R. Cifrino (Michael) of Hingham, MA and Clare R. Butler (David) of Harrison, NY, as well as 27 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Mr. Rooney was an avid golfer and a long time member of Blind Brook Golf Club, Winged Foot Golf Club, Ekwanok Golf Club, Sankaty Head Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, Lyford Cay Club and Lost Tree Club. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Friday from 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection on Saturday at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund. For information go to innercityscholarshipfund.org.

abstract: Investigators are having a hard time determining what made Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crash plane into French Alps since there are so few instances of this, although 'aircraft-assisted pilot suicide,' as it is known, is not without precedent.
headline: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Rare but Not Without Precedent
paragraph: If Andreas Lubitz, the flight’s 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an airplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill passengers and other crew members in the process.
text: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Rare but Not Without Precedent If Andreas Lubitz, the flight’s 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an airplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill passengers and other crew members in the process. Investigators are having a hard time determining what made Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crash plane into French Alps since there are so few instances of this, although 'aircraft-assisted pilot suicide,' as it is known, is not without precedent.

headline: BBC Drops 'Top Gear' Presenter Clarkson Over Attack
paragraph: The BBC on Wednesday dropped British "Top Gear" motoring show presenter Jeremy Clarkson, who built a global fan base while repeatedly causing offense with strongly worded views, after finding he had physically attacked a producer.
text: BBC Drops 'Top Gear' Presenter Clarkson Over Attack The BBC on Wednesday dropped British "Top Gear" motoring show presenter Jeremy Clarkson, who built a global fan base while repeatedly causing offense with strongly worded views, after finding he had physically attacked a producer.

headline: US First Lady Urges Cambodian Students to Seek More Freedoms
paragraph: Michelle Obama urged Cambodian students to finish their education and speak up to demand greater freedoms and more equality on a landmark visit to a Southeast Asian country that has been ruled by an authoritarian strongman for decades.
text: US First Lady Urges Cambodian Students to Seek More Freedoms Michelle Obama urged Cambodian students to finish their education and speak up to demand greater freedoms and more equality on a landmark visit to a Southeast Asian country that has been ruled by an authoritarian strongman for decades.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONESE, EUGENE P. SR.
paragraph: CONESE--Eugene P. Sr.,It is with profound grief that we write about the passing of Mr. Eugene P. Conese, Sr., loving husband, adoring father, devoted son, brother a warm and giving friend that was willing to share his insights, advice and wisdom. Gene's life was one of dedication and love, and he positively impacted the lives of countless people during his life. There are no words to describe the enormous void he will leave behind in his family, his community, and his extensive circle of friends and associates. Gene began his new journey on Thursday, March 19th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep. He will be remembered for his great life stories which he wrote in his memoir, Making Memories - The Story of my Life. His dedication to his family ensured a strong bond between all generations. His legacy is his defining characteristics of integrity, loyalty and generosity. He leaves behind his wife of 60 years, Anna May, and his two daughters and two sons and their spouses, Deborah and Jim Eagan, Susan and Peter Metzger, Eugene and Marianne Conese, Jr., Mark and Cynthia Conese; his ten grandchildren and their spouses, Amanda (Metzger) and Matt DeSocio, Melissa (Metzger) and Steve Finkelstein, Jeffrey Metzger, Kendall Eagan, Meredith Eagan, Conor Eagan, Caroline Conese, Jaqueline (Conese) and Matt Johnson, Christine Conese, Katherine Conese; and two great grandchildren, Ella and Jordan DeSocio. He is also survived by his sister Mary Bertoncini, brother-in-law, Renny Bertoncini, his sister Anita Healy, his sister-in-law, Nancy Hermann, seven nieces and nephews and nine great nieces and nephews. His steadfast commitment to his family and those he loved made him a role model to everyone. Gene was born in Eastchester, NY on August 1st, 1929 the son of Frances and Frank Conese. He graduated from Iona College in 1951 with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree. In 1954, after serving in the Korean War, he earned his MBA from NYU. In 1976 he received an honorary Beta Gamma Sigma Award from St. John's University. In 1977, a speech Mr. Conese gave as a panelist with investment bankers to New York business leaders was published in Vital Speeches of the Day. In 1992, in recognition of Mr. Coneses Outstanding Achievement as an Entrepreneur, he was awarded the Iona College Alumni Association's Brother Arthur A. Loftus Award. He has served with distinction and commitment as a member of the board of trustees and contributing generously to both the Vision into Reality and Visions of Excellence capital campaigns. In 2001, Iona conferred on Mr. Conese the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. In recognition of Mr. Conese's service and contributions to Iona College over the years, in 2008 its principal student dormitory was named after him and is now and forever known as Conese Hall. Eugene P. Conese, Sr. was the founder, Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer of Greenwich Air Services, Inc. until its sale to General Electric in 1997. Under Gene's leadership it became the world's largest independent jet engine overhaul and rebuilding service company as well as one of the world's largest business and regional aircraft ground maintenance, parts and engine repair companies. It had offices in North America, Europe, Asia and the Middle East, with plants throughout the U.S. and Europe and employed over 10,000 people at the time of the sale to General Electric. Mr. Conese was the winner of the prestigious Wright Brothers Memorial Award (1996) from the Greater Miami Aviation Association. In 1997, Greenwich Air Services, under Mr. Conese's leadership, was awarded the Emerging Company Award by the South Florida Chapter of the Association for Corporate Growth in Miami (prior recipients include Office Depot, Blockbuster Entertainment and Sunglass Hut). Mr. Conese had also served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Jackson Memorial Foundation which leads fundraising activities and resources on behalf of Miami-Dade County's Public Health Trust, which operates Jackson Memorial Hospital of Miami, Florida. In March of 2004, Mr. Conese's name was permanently inscribed on the Smithsonian's National Aviation and Space Exploration Wall of Honor as a leader in aviation and space exploration. In November of 2009, Mr. Conese received the 2010 Ellis Island Congressional Medal of Honor in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the community. He had a larger than life persona, was an inspiring leader who will be missed by all that ever had the opportunity to meet him, a loving husband, wonderful father and a true friend. There will be a Wake Service on Monday, March 23, 2015 from 6-9pm at Van Orsdel Funeral Chapel at 4600 SW 8th Street, Coral Gables, FL 33134 and there will be a Funeral Mass on Tuesday, March 24,, 2015 at 11:30am at St. Hugh Catholic Church, 3460 Royal Road, Coconut Grove, Florida 33133. 1/3

headline: Dallas Death Points to Dangers of Black-Market Cosmetic Work
paragraph: The recent death of a Dallas woman who had received injections at a salon to expand the size of her buttocks follows other cosmetic-related deaths in Texas and around the country that authorities say were caused by people who either weren't licensed or who injected substances not approved by federal regulators.
text: Dallas Death Points to Dangers of Black-Market Cosmetic Work The recent death of a Dallas woman who had received injections at a salon to expand the size of her buttocks follows other cosmetic-related deaths in Texas and around the country that authorities say were caused by people who either weren't licensed or who injected substances not approved by federal regulators.

headline: Parents Seeking Urban Lifestyles for Kids
paragraph: A small but growing number of parents are bucking a trend when it comes to raising their kids: Rather than move to suburbs as their parents once did, many are opting to stay in or near downtown.
text: Parents Seeking Urban Lifestyles for Kids A small but growing number of parents are bucking a trend when it comes to raising their kids: Rather than move to suburbs as their parents once did, many are opting to stay in or near downtown.

abstract: Letter from climate scientists and environmental groups asserts that museums of science and natural history should 'cut all ties' with fossil fuel companies and donors like Koch brothers; says their donations are tainted by their attempts to deny climate change.

paragraph: Donations from fossil fuel companies and others who deny climate change are tainted, a letter from scientists and environmental groups says.
text: Science Museums Urged to Cut Ties With Kochs Donations from fossil fuel companies and others who deny climate change are tainted, a letter from scientists and environmental groups says. Letter from climate scientists and environmental groups asserts that museums of science and natural history should 'cut all ties' with fossil fuel companies and donors like Koch brothers; says their donations are tainted by their attempts to deny climate change.

headline: Justices Struggle With Free Speech Case Over License Plates
paragraph: In a dispute over a proposed Confederate battle flag license plate, the Supreme Court struggled Monday to balance worries about government censorship and concerns that offensive messages could, at worst, incite violence.
text: Justices Struggle With Free Speech Case Over License Plates In a dispute over a proposed Confederate battle flag license plate, the Supreme Court struggled Monday to balance worries about government censorship and concerns that offensive messages could, at worst, incite violence.

headline: Suspect in Arizona Shootings Had Troubled Past, Records Show
paragraph: He had a long rap sheet that dated back more than 20 years and included convictions in three states. He struggled with drug abuse and at one point got a tattoo on his forehead that read "skinhead."

headline: Civilians Pay the Price for Expanding Conflict in Yemen
paragraph: Violence in Yemen has killed an estimated 519 people the past two weeks, 90 of them children, and tens of thousands are fleeing their homes, the U.N. humanitarian chief said Thursday, signs of the humanitarian damage being wreaked in the Arab world's poorest nation in the rapid escalation of its conflict.
text: Civilians Pay the Price for Expanding Conflict in Yemen Violence in Yemen has killed an estimated 519 people the past two weeks, 90 of them children, and tens of thousands are fleeing their homes, the U.N. humanitarian chief said Thursday, signs of the humanitarian damage being wreaked in the Arab world's poorest nation in the rapid escalation of its conflict.

text: India's IT Plans Suffer From Power Cuts, Congestion-And Monkeys As India launches an $18 billion plan to spread the information revolution to its provinces, the problems it faces are a holdover from the past - electricity shortages, badly planned, jam-packed cities, and monkeys.

abstract: Editorial warns that Pres Obama's decision to slow troop withdrawal from Afghanistan cannot be used as excuse to leave troops in country indefinitely; calls on Obama and Afghan Pres Ashraf Ghani to prove that American troop presence will be worth it; cautions that despite Ghani's expressed goal of making Afghanistan self-sustaining, it is at this point only based on hope.
headline: Afghanistan’s Next Chapter
paragraph: Will the additional American investment prove to be worth it?
text: Afghanistan’s Next Chapter  Will the additional American investment prove to be worth it? Editorial warns that Pres Obama's decision to slow troop withdrawal from Afghanistan cannot be used as excuse to leave troops in country indefinitely; calls on Obama and Afghan Pres Ashraf Ghani to prove that American troop presence will be worth it; cautions that despite Ghani's expressed goal of making Afghanistan self-sustaining, it is at this point only based on hope.

headline: Popular Nevada Governor Looms Over Fight for Reid Seat
paragraph: Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid's decision to retire next year leaves no clear successor in his home state of Nevada, where a popular Republican governor appears reluctant to change jobs and the pending loss of Reid's clout in Washington is causing anxiety over who might replace him.
text: Popular Nevada Governor Looms Over Fight for Reid Seat Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid's decision to retire next year leaves no clear successor in his home state of Nevada, where a popular Republican governor appears reluctant to change jobs and the pending loss of Reid's clout in Washington is causing anxiety over who might replace him.

headline: Co-Pilot Was 'Very Happy' With Germanwings Job

headline: Tax Refund Advances Appeal to More Cash-Strapped Americans
paragraph: Cash-strapped Americans anxious for tax refunds are increasingly turning to payment advances, prepaid cards or other costly services when getting tax preparation help, according to new federal data raising concerns among regulators about whether consumers are fully informed about the fees.

headline: A Look at How Residential Colleges Work at Some Schools
paragraph: Colleges are confronting the related problems of sexual assault and drinking with a mix of solutions, some aimed at changing an ingrained culture that encourages irresponsible behavior. Dartmouth College appears to be the only school responding by completely overhauling its housing into a system of "residential colleges" — a concept that goes back centuries in England but exists at only about 30 U.S. schools.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, FRANCIS C. FRANCIS C. ROONEY, JR.
paragraph: ROONEY--Francis C. Francis C. Rooney, Jr.,the Chairman of H.H. Brown Shoe Company and the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Melville Corporation, died on March 24, 2015 at Greenwich Hospital. He was 93 years old. Rooney was married for 65 years to the love of his life, the former Frances Heffernan of Worcester, Massachusetts. One of the leading retail executives of his generation, Rooney transformed Melville Corporation from a shoe company with $180 million in revenue at the time he became chief executive officer at age 42 into a specialty retail business with over $7 billion of revenue at the time of his retirement in 1987. In 1987, Melville's businesses included Marshall's, Linens & Things, K.B. Toys and CVS Drug Stores. Today the company's name has changed from Melville Corp to CVS Health Corporation. In 1990, after three years of retirement, Rooney agreed to become CEO of H.H. Brown Shoe Co., Inc., which was owned by his late father-in -law. In 1991, the company was sold to Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and at Warren Buffett?s request he became Chairman. In a press interview, Mr. Buffett concluded, Frank "is a sensational human being and a great manager." Throughout his adult life Rooney maintained a commitment to numerous civic, charitable and education causes. He was one of the founding trustees of the Inner City Scholarship Fund, which today provides over 30,000 inner city children with scholarships to attend Catholic schools in New York City. He also served as a trustee of United Cerebral Palsy; Greenwich Hospital; March of Dimes; Smithsonian Institute; Boys & Girls Club of America; St. Ignatius School in the Bronx; The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania; Pace University; and Fordham University. In 1987, Rooney received an honorary degree from Boston College. In addition, Rooney served on the Board of Directors of Bankers Trust Company; Collins & Aikman Textile Company; ADT; AMF Corporation; Black & Decker; Dunkin Donuts; and Neiman Markus. Frank Rooney was born at home in North Brookfield, Massachusetts on Thanksgiving Day, November 24, 1921. He graduated in 1939 from North Brookfield High School where he was captain of the basketball team, and he received his bachelor degree from the University of Pennsylvania (Wharton School) in 1943. He graduated as an Ensign in the U.S. Naval Reserve and was assigned that year to the battleship USS North Carolina in the Pacific. He was aboard as a gunnery officer in 10 major engagements between 1943 and 1945. He began his business career in 1946 as a sales trainee with the John Foote Shoe Company in Brockton, Massachusetts. Two years later, he went to work for the Florsheim Shoe Company in Chicago, and in 1953 he joined the Thom McAn Shoe Company, a subsidiary of Melville Shoe Corporation, as a buyer/ stylist. He rose to President of Thom McAn in 1961 and in 1964 he was elected Chairman, President and CEO of Melville Shoe Corporation. Mr. Rooney is survived by his beloved wife Frances Heffernan and eight children: Peter M. Rooney (Kathy) of Basking Ridge, NJ; Michael F. Rooney (Joann) of New Rochelle, NY; Stephen G. Rooney (Susan) of Pelham Manor, NY; Jean R. Weil (Jerry) of Greenwich, CT; William A. Rooney (Amy) of Charlotte, NC; Carol R. Flanagan (James) of Greenwich, CT; Frances R. Cifrino (Michael) of Hingham, MA and Clare R. Butler (David) of Harrison, NY, as well as 27 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Mr. Rooney was an avid golfer and a long time member of Blind Brook Golf Club, Winged Foot Golf Club, Ekwanok Golf Club, Sankaty Head Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, Lyford Cay Club and Lost Tree Club. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580 on Friday from 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Resurrection on Saturday at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund. For information go to innercityscholarshipfund.org. 1/3

headline: After Cyclone Pam, Vanuatu Revives, Rebuilds and Rethinks
paragraph: The roof from what was once the home of principal Melizabeth Uhi and her staff is now folded over branches high in the trees that border her school. She's now living with two other staff members in the only classroom that's still habitable. And she's running low on the rice she had before Cyclone Pam tore through Vanuatu a week ago, upending her life.

headline: Mass Killing of Dogs Shocks City in Northern Mexico
paragraph: Somebody is systematically poisoning the dogs of Hermosillo, an industrial city in northern Mexico, and not just strays: At least 64 dogs, all with owners, have died of a similar poison since mid-March. More stray animals have probably been killed, but had no one to file a complaint, authorities say.

headline: Supreme Court Considers Impact of Disability Law on Police
paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday seemed skeptical that the nation's disabilities law requires police to take special precautions when arresting armed and violent suspects who are mentally ill. Most justices expressed doubts about second-guessing police who are trying to protect public safety.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONESE, EUGENE
paragraph: CONESE--Eugene P. Sr., It is with profound grief that we write about the passing of Mr. Eugene P. Conese, Sr., loving husband, adoring father, devoted son, brother a warm and giving friend that was willing to share his insights, advice and wisdom. Gene's life was one of dedication and love, and he positively impacted the lives of countless people during his life. There are no words to describe the enormous void he will leave behind in his family, his community, and his extensive circle of friends and associates. Gene began his new journey on Thursday, March 19th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep. He will be remembered for his great life stories which he wrote in his memoir, Making Memories - The Story of my Life. His dedication to his family ensured a strong bond between all generations. His legacy is his defining characteristics of integrity, loyalty and generosity. He leaves behind his wife of 60 years, Anna May, and his two daughters and two sons and their spouses, Deborah and Jim Eagan, Susan and Peter Metzger, Eugene and Marianne Conese, Jr., Mark and Cynthia Conese; his ten grandchildren and their spouses, Amanda (Metzger) and Matt DeSocio, Melissa (Metzger) and Steve Finkelstein, Jeffrey Metzger, Kendall Eagan, Meredith Eagan, Conor Eagan, Caroline Conese, Jaqueline (Conese) and Matt Johnson, Christine Conese, Katherine Conese; and two great grandchildren, Ella and Jordan DeSocio. He is also survived by his sister Mary Bertoncini, brother-in-law, Renny Bertoncini, his sister Anita Healy, his sister-in-law, Nancy Hermann, seven nieces and nephews and nine great nieces and nephews. His steadfast commitment to his family and those he loved made him a role model to everyone. Gene was born in Eastchester, NY on August 1st, 1929 the son of Frances and Frank Conese. He graduated from Iona College in 1951 with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree. In 1954, after serving in the Korean War, he earned his MBA from NYU. In 1976 he received an honorary Beta Gamma Sigma Award from St. John's University. In 1977, a speech Mr. Conese gave as a panelist with investment bankers to New York business leaders was published in Vital Speeches of the Day. In 1992, in recognition of Mr. Coneses Outstanding Achievement as an Entrepreneur, he was awarded the Iona College Alumni Association's Brother Arthur A. Loftus Award. He has served with distinction and commitment as a member of the board of trustees and contributing generously to both the Vision into Reality and Visions of Excellence capital campaigns. In 2001, Iona conferred on Mr. Conese the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. In recognition of Mr. Conese's service and contributions to Iona College over the years, in 2008 its principal student dormitory was named after him and is now and forever known as Conese Hall. Eugene P. Conese, Sr. was the founder, Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer of Greenwich Air Services, Inc. until its sale to General Electric in 1997. Under Gene's leadership it became the world's largest independent jet engine overhaul and rebuilding service company as well as one of the world's largest business and regional aircraft ground maintenance, parts and engine repair companies. It had offices in North America, Europe, Asia and the Middle East, with plants throughout the U.S. and Europe and employed over 10,000 people at the time of the sale to General Electric. Mr. Conese was the winner of the prestigious Wright Brothers Memorial Award (1996) from the Greater Miami Aviation Association. In 1997, Greenwich Air Services, under Mr. Conese's leadership, was awarded the Emerging Company Award by the South Florida Chapter of the Association for Corporate Growth in Miami (prior recipients include Office Depot, Blockbuster Entertainment and Sunglass Hut). Mr. Conese had also served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Jackson Memorial Foundation which leads fundraising activities and resources on behalf of Miami-Dade County's Public Health Trust, which operates Jackson Memorial Hospital of Miami, Florida. In March of 2004, Mr. Conese's name was permanently inscribed on the Smithsonian's National Aviation and Space Exploration Wall of Honor as a leader in aviation and space exploration. In November of 2009, Mr. Conese received the 2010 Ellis Island Congressional Medal of Honor in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the community. He had a larger than life persona, was an inspiring leader who will be missed by all that ever had the opportunity to meet him, a loving husband, wonderful father and a true friend. There will be a Wake Service on Monday, March 23, 2015 from 6-9pm at Van Orsdel Funeral Chapel at 4600 SW 8th Street, Coral Gables, FL 33134 and there will be a Funeral Mass on Tuesday, March 24,, 2015 at 11:30am at St. Hugh Catholic Church, 3460 Royal Road, Coconut Grove, Florida 33133.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column examines why conservatives and Republicans are skeptical about job growth and economic recovery that is occurring nationally and in state of California; posits that job growth in wake of passage of Affordable Care Act directly conflicts with Republican predictions of economic doom, and that California's growth despite its resistance to tax-cutting and deregulation threatens basis of conservative fiscal thought.

abstract: Departure of Richard W Fisher from Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, where he has been president for a decade, marks loss of one of the most vocal opponents of Fed's stimulus campaign even as that campaign comes to end; Fisher was known for eloquent arguments that were often more colorful than any of those of his colleagues, and often angered those who believed Fed should do more to help unemployed.

abstract: Coalition of Sunni Islamist insurgent groups, including Al Qaeda’s Nusra Front, takes control of Idlib, Syria, leaving residents to wonder how they will be governed; diverse warring factions across country have made complex map of control.
headline: An Anxious Wait in Syrian City Held by Insurgents

headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founder of Modern Singapore, Dies at 91
