headline: Fracking: US Tightens Rules for Chemical Disclosure
paragraph: The Obama administration said Friday it is requiring companies that drill for oil and natural gas on federal lands to disclose chemicals used in hydraulic fracturing, the first major federal regulation of the controversial drilling technique that has sparked an ongoing boom in natural gas production but raised widespread concerns about possible groundwater contamination.

abstract: Millions of tax dollars from recreational marijuana sales are flooding Colorado's coffers, but due to anti-spending provision in state's Constitution, it may have to refund nearly $60 million to drug's consumers, growers and the public; lawmakers are hoping Colorado's generally anti-tax public will approve bill allowing state to keep money for school construction and other needs.
headline: In Colorado, Marijuana Taxes May Have to Be Passed Back
paragraph: A strict anti-spending provision in the state Constitution may force Colorado to refund nearly $60 million intended for school construction and other needs.
text: In Colorado, Marijuana Taxes May Have to Be Passed Back A strict anti-spending provision in the state Constitution may force Colorado to refund nearly $60 million intended for school construction and other needs. Millions of tax dollars from recreational marijuana sales are flooding Colorado's coffers, but due to anti-spending provision in state's Constitution, it may have to refund nearly $60 million to drug's consumers, growers and the public; lawmakers are hoping Colorado's generally anti-tax public will approve bill allowing state to keep money for school construction and other needs.

abstract: Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford's hand-drawn coloring books for adults have become global best-sellers; Secret Garden, with black-and-white ink drawings of flowers, leaves, trees and birds has sold more than 1.4 million copies in 22 languages; adults find coloring the drawings relaxing; major publishers are jumping on trend.
headline: Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons
paragraph: Johanna Basford, a Scottish illustrator, has become a breakout success catering to an unexpected audience: adults who turn to coloring books for creative relaxation.
text: Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons Johanna Basford, a Scottish illustrator, has become a breakout success catering to an unexpected audience: adults who turn to coloring books for creative relaxation. Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford's hand-drawn coloring books for adults have become global best-sellers; Secret Garden, with black-and-white ink drawings of flowers, leaves, trees and birds has sold more than 1.4 million copies in 22 languages; adults find coloring the drawings relaxing; major publishers are jumping on trend.

abstract: Sen Ted Cruz is set to announce in formal speech at Liberty University that he is officially seeking Republican nomination in 2016 presidential election; decision to declare himself officially is calculated to catapult his candidacy to forefront, even as conservatives may have begun considering other possible candidates.
headline: Ted Cruz Hopes Early Campaign Entry Will Focus Voters’ Attention
paragraph: By becoming the first candidate to officially enter the presidential race, the Texas senator hopes to reclaim the attention of those in the G.O.P.’s right wing.
text: Ted Cruz Hopes Early Campaign Entry Will Focus Voters’ Attention By becoming the first candidate to officially enter the presidential race, the Texas senator hopes to reclaim the attention of those in the G.O.P.’s right wing. Sen Ted Cruz is set to announce in formal speech at Liberty University that he is officially seeking Republican nomination in 2016 presidential election; decision to declare himself officially is calculated to catapult his candidacy to forefront, even as conservatives may have begun considering other possible candidates.

headline: Islamic State Says It Killed Tourists in Tunisia
paragraph: Tunisia said it would deploy the army to major cities and arrested nine people on Thursday after 20 foreign tourists were shot dead in an attack on a museum which Islamic State militants called "the first drop of the rain".
text: Islamic State Says It Killed Tourists in Tunisia Tunisia said it would deploy the army to major cities and arrested nine people on Thursday after 20 foreign tourists were shot dead in an attack on a museum which Islamic State militants called "the first drop of the rain".

abstract: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel is trying to soften his image in lead-up to runoff election; tactic seems to be acknowledgment of fact that his abrasive personality and hardball tactics may have turned enough voters off for him to fail to win more than 50 percent of vote in February; Emanuel has tried to convey to voters that he is cognizant of brash ways he may have dealt with issues in his first term, as in his treatment of unions and decision to close public schools.
headline: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s Rough-Edged Mayor, Tries the Sandpaper
paragraph: As a runoff with Jesus G. Garcia approaches next Tuesday, some voters say they have soured on hardball tactics and gruffness.
text: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s Rough-Edged Mayor, Tries the Sandpaper As a runoff with Jesus G. Garcia approaches next Tuesday, some voters say they have soured on hardball tactics and gruffness. Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel is trying to soften his image in lead-up to runoff election; tactic seems to be acknowledgment of fact that his abrasive personality and hardball tactics may have turned enough voters off for him to fail to win more than 50 percent of vote in February; Emanuel has tried to convey to voters that he is cognizant of brash ways he may have dealt with issues in his first term, as in his treatment of unions and decision to close public schools.

abstract: Growth in traffic at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta international Airport has leveled off in past decade and is hardly increasing; it had more than 76 million passengers in 2014; city officials say hub is critical to local economic growth and are increasing efforts to attract businesses.
headline: In Atlanta, a Quest to Keep Its Airport the World’s Busiest
paragraph: The city’s officials say they believe its bustling hub has been crucial to local economic growth and have intensified efforts to attract businesses.
text: In Atlanta, a Quest to Keep Its Airport the World’s Busiest The city’s officials say they believe its bustling hub has been crucial to local economic growth and have intensified efforts to attract businesses. Growth in traffic at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta international Airport has leveled off in past decade and is hardly increasing; it had more than 76 million passengers in 2014; city officials say hub is critical to local economic growth and are increasing efforts to attract businesses.

abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column maintains economic inequality is gravest challenge facing society today; suggests that combining massive public works program and guaranteed welfare is best top-down solution for short term; calls for resolution and pursuit of more egalitarian system than current capitalist one.
headline: Why Not Utopia?
paragraph: We need a future where the robots benefit all of us, not just the rich.
text: Why Not Utopia? We need a future where the robots benefit all of us, not just the rich. Mark Bittman Op-Ed column maintains economic inequality is gravest challenge facing society today; suggests that combining massive public works program and guaranteed welfare is best top-down solution for short term; calls for resolution and pursuit of more egalitarian system than current capitalist one.

abstract: Wim Wenders and Juliano Salgado, son of Brazilian photographer Sebastiao Salgado, explore the elder Salgado's work in documentary The Salt of the Earth.
headline: ‘The Salt of the Earth’ Presents a Photographer’s Life and Lens, in Focus
paragraph: “The Salt of the Earth,” directed by Wim Wenders and Juliano Salgado, examines the photography of Juliano’s father, Sebastião Salgado, and sometimes strained family dynamics.
text: ‘The Salt of the Earth’ Presents a Photographer’s Life and Lens, in Focus “The Salt of the Earth,” directed by Wim Wenders and Juliano Salgado, examines the photography of Juliano’s father, Sebastião Salgado, and sometimes strained family dynamics. Wim Wenders and Juliano Salgado, son of Brazilian photographer Sebastiao Salgado, explore the elder Salgado's work in documentary The Salt of the Earth.

headline: Frats Are Finding Themselves Under Fire for Bad Behavior
paragraph: Racist chants. Nude photos of unconscious women. A criminal investigation into hazing. Fraternities around the country seem to be coming under fire as never before over behavior that would shock the frat boys of "Animal House."
text: Frats Are Finding Themselves Under Fire for Bad Behavior Racist chants. Nude photos of unconscious women. A criminal investigation into hazing. Fraternities around the country seem to be coming under fire as never before over behavior that would shock the frat boys of "Animal House."

abstract: Expected Republican presidential candidates Jeb Bush and Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker have set off down two different paths to the White House, revealing larger debate within the GOP; Bush envisions party that can expand its reach by accepting social change and welcoming different types of voters into its ranks; Walker, by contrast, seems intent on energizing base by confronting adversaries and striking well-established political tones.
headline: Jeb Bush and Scott Walker Point G.O.P. to Contrary Paths
paragraph: Mr. Bush and Mr. Walker are becoming prominent exponents of dueling visions of how a Republican can retake the White House: by extending the party’s reach, or by energizing the base.
text: Jeb Bush and Scott Walker Point G.O.P. to Contrary Paths Mr. Bush and Mr. Walker are becoming prominent exponents of dueling visions of how a Republican can retake the White House: by extending the party’s reach, or by energizing the base. Expected Republican presidential candidates Jeb Bush and Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker have set off down two different paths to the White House, revealing larger debate within the GOP; Bush envisions party that can expand its reach by accepting social change and welcoming different types of voters into its ranks; Walker, by contrast, seems intent on energizing base by confronting adversaries and striking well-established political tones.

abstract: News Analysis; little-known branch of psychology known as perceptual learning has become increasingly relevant as scientists are confronted with massive amounts of abstract digital data; for now, many researchers bring in visually creative experts to offer insight into visual data, but research has shown that perceptual training can enhance scientists abilities to pick up on patterns themselves.
headline: Learning to See Data
paragraph: Developing instinctual learning can help scientists see patterns in the digital universe.
text: Learning to See Data Developing instinctual learning can help scientists see patterns in the digital universe. News Analysis; little-known branch of psychology known as perceptual learning has become increasingly relevant as scientists are confronted with massive amounts of abstract digital data; for now, many researchers bring in visually creative experts to offer insight into visual data, but research has shown that perceptual training can enhance scientists abilities to pick up on patterns themselves.

abstract: Florida's decision to mandate protective headgear for high school girl's lacrosse has ignited firestorm with national implications; critics say headgear is ineffective, flimsy, uncomfortable and could potentially lead to more hazardous play.
headline: Headgear Rule for Girls’ Lacrosse Ignites Outcry
paragraph: The Florida High School Athletic Association wanted players to wear protective headgear, but the decision left the sport’s national governing body, coaches and players fuming.
text: Headgear Rule for Girls’ Lacrosse Ignites Outcry The Florida High School Athletic Association wanted players to wear protective headgear, but the decision left the sport’s national governing body, coaches and players fuming. Florida's decision to mandate protective headgear for high school girl's lacrosse has ignited firestorm with national implications; critics say headgear is ineffective, flimsy, uncomfortable and could potentially lead to more hazardous play.

headline: House Roll Call: Republicans Approve Conservative Budget
paragraph: The 228-199 roll call Wednesday by which the House passed a conservative budget that relies on nearly $5 trillion in cuts to eliminate deficits over the next decade, calls for repealing the health care law and envisions transformations of the tax code and Medicare.
text: House Roll Call: Republicans Approve Conservative Budget The 228-199 roll call Wednesday by which the House passed a conservative budget that relies on nearly $5 trillion in cuts to eliminate deficits over the next decade, calls for repealing the health care law and envisions transformations of the tax code and Medicare.

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has never been a churchgoer, has unexpectedly become an advocate for religion in the most public of arenas; from including time for prayers in prekindergarten classes to siding with ultra-Orthodox Jews in oversight of circumcision, de Blasio has pitted himself against some of his own allies, who criticize him for his sharp redefining of separation between church and state.
headline: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion
paragraph: In finding new ways to commingle church and state, Bill de Blasio has carved himself a niche as a liberal who is willing to embrace religious groups rather than treat them as adversaries.
text: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion In finding new ways to commingle church and state, Bill de Blasio has carved himself a niche as a liberal who is willing to embrace religious groups rather than treat them as adversaries. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has never been a churchgoer, has unexpectedly become an advocate for religion in the most public of arenas; from including time for prayers in prekindergarten classes to siding with ultra-Orthodox Jews in oversight of circumcision, de Blasio has pitted himself against some of his own allies, who criticize him for his sharp redefining of separation between church and state.

abstract: Illegal hunting operations in Vietnam are threatening existence of several species of rare wild animals, as poachers seek to capitalize off of demand for exotic meats and ingredients in traditional medicines; stemming illegal trade has proved difficult in Vietnam, where few protections exist and conservation is not high priority.
headline: In Vietnam, Rampant Wildlife Smuggling Prompts Little Concern
paragraph: Several species, valued as food, medicine or pets, may become extinct in a country where punishment is light or nonexistent.
text: In Vietnam, Rampant Wildlife Smuggling Prompts Little Concern Several species, valued as food, medicine or pets, may become extinct in a country where punishment is light or nonexistent. Illegal hunting operations in Vietnam are threatening existence of several species of rare wild animals, as poachers seek to capitalize off of demand for exotic meats and ingredients in traditional medicines; stemming illegal trade has proved difficult in Vietnam, where few protections exist and conservation is not high priority.

abstract: Latisha Fisher of Manhattan is charged with murder of her 1-year-old son after she locked herself in restroom of Midtown hamburger restaurant with him and refused help while he lost consciousness; police have not said publicly how child was killed; she had been taking medication for her paranoid schizophrenia and had begun community college classes.
headline: Fleeting Stability for a Woman Charged With Killing Her Son
paragraph: Latisha Fisher, who was taking medication to treat her paranoid schizophrenia and had started community college classes, locked herself and her son in the restroom of a Midtown restaurant.
text: Fleeting Stability for a Woman Charged With Killing Her Son Latisha Fisher, who was taking medication to treat her paranoid schizophrenia and had started community college classes, locked herself and her son in the restroom of a Midtown restaurant. Latisha Fisher of Manhattan is charged with murder of her 1-year-old son after she locked herself in restroom of Midtown hamburger restaurant with him and refused help while he lost consciousness; police have not said publicly how child was killed; she had been taking medication for her paranoid schizophrenia and had begun community college classes.

paragraph: The relationship between Mr. Durst and Debrah Lee Charatan, who supported him once before when he was accused of murder, has taken a sharp turn in recent years.

abstract: Organizers are planning for April 15 gathering to change fast-food workers' struggle for $15 hourly wage into national movement of all low-wage workers; demonstration is meant to bring pressure on McDonald's and tie the spirit of labor organizing with banner of civil rights.
headline: Movement to Increase McDonald’s Minimum Wage Broadens Its Tactics
paragraph: Unions in the United States and elsewhere are increasing pressure on the fast-food giant by protesting its corporate practices to government bodies as well as planning strikes.

abstract: Kodak, having emerged from bankruptcy in 2013, is attempting to regain some of its once-powerful position through research and development; staff of some 300 scientists and engineers are mining company's rich trove of patents for ideas that can be given new relevance.
headline: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film
paragraph: What happens when a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak, the answer is to mine its patents for gold. (With video.)
text: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film  What happens when a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak, the answer is to mine its patents for gold. (With video.) Kodak, having emerged from bankruptcy in 2013, is attempting to regain some of its once-powerful position through research and development; staff of some 300 scientists and engineers are mining company's rich trove of patents for ideas that can be given new relevance.

abstract: Judith Shulevitz Op-Ed article highlights examples from colleges and universities where students have pushed to curb debate or for establishment of 'safe spaces' to shield them from trauma that may result from unpopular opinions; questions whether approach is breeding environment antithetical to open and free expression of ideas, which is crucial for college education.
headline: In College and Hiding From Scary Ideas
paragraph: Universities, rather than being forums for free expression, are encouraging “safe spaces” to protect delicate sensibilities.

abstract: Girls basketball team at Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens, is known as athletic powerhouse and draws students who are serious about game from all over New York City; has played important role in raising profile of girls' sports in city; has not won state championship since 2010, however, and current players are striving to bring team back to former glory.
headline: For an Elite Girls’ Basketball Team, the Same High Standards Amid New Challenges
paragraph: A writer who chronicled the season of the girls’ basketball team at Christ the King High School in Queens 16 years ago returned for an update.
text: For an Elite Girls’ Basketball Team, the Same High Standards Amid New Challenges A writer who chronicled the season of the girls’ basketball team at Christ the King High School in Queens 16 years ago returned for an update. Girls basketball team at Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens, is known as athletic powerhouse and draws students who are serious about game from all over New York City; has played important role in raising profile of girls' sports in city; has not won state championship since 2010, however, and current players are striving to bring team back to former glory.

abstract: Ben Carson, pediatric neurosurgeon who burst on to the political scene in 2013 as a controversial novelty, is now looking to be seen as a serious Republican contender for 2016 presidential nomination; hard-right candidacy like Carson's presents new kind of challenge to GOP, which has been selecting establishment nominees since at least 1980.
headline: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Ben Carson?
paragraph: His chances of victory are minuscule, but he and other hard-right candidates will still be a headache for the G.O.P. in the 2016 primaries. Can mainstream Republicans stop him? Should they try?
text: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Ben Carson? His chances of victory are minuscule, but he and other hard-right candidates will still be a headache for the G.O.P. in the 2016 primaries. Can mainstream Republicans stop him? Should they try? Ben Carson, pediatric neurosurgeon who burst on to the political scene in 2013 as a controversial novelty, is now looking to be seen as a serious Republican contender for 2016 presidential nomination; hard-right candidacy like Carson's presents new kind of challenge to GOP, which has been selecting establishment nominees since at least 1980.
